Service delivery protesters burn tires, block roads and throw rocks a police in the Isipingo area.
EFF supporters clash with ANC supporters at the land reform event attended by both parties. Members of several unions also clashed at the event following an exchange of insults.

Boulders and rubbish barricaded the streets of Bekkersdal on Thursday night as residents continued to call on their mayor to step down and the municipality to be placed under administration. The residents were upset of the state of the sewage system infrastructure.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Three union members were taken to hospital and a woman fell down a flight of stairs after scuffles broke out at Unisa's Pretoria campus between Nehawu and Sasco members. The groups were attending a land reform event.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: AMCU union members protest their employers retrenchment process.
Two factions of the ANC clash at a party meeting, causing several injuries. The two group were at disagreement over an electoral nomination process.
A protest led by ANC ward councillor Andile Lili marches through the Cape Flats and CBD area to push on higher standards of sanitation practices, land and housing.
Service delivery protesters burn tires along the N1 expressway connecting Pretoria and Sandton.
A woman was shot and killed and another injured by police in a housing riot in Cato Manor, Durban. When police forces arrive to disperse the crowd the riots threw stones at the police vehicle.

A woman was shot and killed and another injured by police in a housing riot in Cato Manor, Durban. When police forces arrive to disperse the crowd the riots threw stones at the police vehicle. The police later expressed regret of the shooting.
Protesters at Mooiplaas informal settlement in Pretoria West stoned police. The protest was believed to have been related to service delivery grievances.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Police shot rubber bullets and teargas at a group of AMCU members holding a mass meeting. Several members of the union were arrested, others injured.
A group of animal rights activists and motorcycle enthusiasts march in protest of elephant poaching.
Red Location residents protest demanding the government provide them with houses.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Municipal workers of the SAMWU march in King Williams Town and Bhisho in support of suspended Cosatu general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi. Mr Vavi was suspended in August for allegedly bringing Cosatu into disrepute after he admitted having an affair with an employee.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Municipal workers of the SAMWU march in King Williams Town and Bhisho in support of suspended Cosatu general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi. Mr Vavi was suspended in August for allegedly bringing Cosatu into disrepute after he admitted having an affair with an employee.

Central Business District parking marshals march in protest of employment grievances. The marshals are members of SA Transport and Allied Workers Union, though they organized this protest independent of the union.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Striking members of FAWU ""behave violently"" during a protest over wage demands.

A member of Agang SA was assaulted and killed in Limpopo after attending the parties branch launch in Uitkyk, Bochum. The victim was wearing a political t-shirt at the time, which is believed to be the motive of the assailants.
Police use rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse a group of University of Limpopo students who began a violent protest following the outcome of a university election.

Members of the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) threatened to shutdown the Evraz Vametco mine outside Brits, North West, demanding better wages. The group staged a protest to make their demands known.
A visiting delegation of Kazakh officials are robbed as they travelled from the airport.
Striking employees of a retail store are fired upon by security personnel of the store when they attempt to enter the premises during protest. Five severely wounded.
A known gangster survives an assassination attempt outside a Western Cape High Court following a hearing in Cape Town. The perpetrator was arrested soon after.
Students at the University of Limpopo protest inter-university politics, smash four cars on campus.
Police forces fired rubber bullets at rioting students who were stoning police vehicles and destroying property. It is not clear why the students were protesting.
A group of Red October protesters march to highlight ""the oppression and violence against white South Africans"".

A group of white framers protest the murders of farmers and other oppression they allegedly suffer. The group of around 400 protesters under the adgis of ""Red October"" marched from Keizergracht to Parliament and released a number of balloons in memory of those murdered.
A man charged with beating a woman to death is escorted by police following a court hearing when the car he entered was attacked by protesters.
Police forces clash with university protesters for the third day. Police again implemented tear gas and rubber bullets.

Red Location residents protest outside the Red Location Museum, which showcases apartheids turbulent past, and demand that money spent on fixing Singaphi Street - which leads to the museum - be used to fix their homes.
Hundreds gathered outside the US Embassy in Pretoria to protest against the U.S.-led ""imperialist aggression in Syria.""
Cape Town parking attendants strike and protest over a ""breach of contract.""
A group of Cookhouse residents barricade the N10 highway, connecting Port Elizabeth and Cradock, demanding to be employed at a nearby wind farm.
Service delivery protesters in Bekkersdal, near Westonaria threw stones at a police station. Several of the protesters were arrested.
Service delivery protesters throw stones at a Bekkerdal police station, police respond with rubber bullets. 35 rioters arrested.
Residents of Malamulele in Limpopo burnt down a government building and shops during a violent demarcation protest. Protesters also burned tires and blocked roads. Forty arrested.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Food and Allied Workers Union (Fawu) begin a labour strike and protest outside a brewery. The groups demands included wage increases and a betterment of working conditions.
Small groups of protesters remain in Malamulele for a second day. The action was not violent.
Residents of a shantytown riot in anger after the bodies of two toddlers are discovered raped and strangled.
ANC operatives attack members of the Mmusi Maimane campaign (DA) with rocks. The group of 100 was bussed in to launch a coordinated attack. Injuries unknown.
A group of rural women protest at the Parliament building against a bill scheduled to be voted on that would harm farmers.
Impala Road near Protea in Soweto had to be closed during the morning hours after Tshepisong residents protested and burnt tires. It is not immediately known why the group was protesting.
Service delivery protesters attack a police station with stones for a second day. Police responded to the attack with rubber bullets.
Service delivery protesters set a Cookhouse set a municipal building alight and stoned police vehicles.
In an effort to make drugs more accessible, health activists protested in Pretoria, calling for overhauling of South Africas patent laws on medicine.
More than 200 people marched to the Shell offices on Cape Towns Foreshore to register their objections to fracking in South Africa.

Angered by the murder of two young girls, police fired rubber bullets to disperse thousands of people after five people were arrested for the rape and murder of the two. The rioters responded by throwing stones at police.
Service delivery protesters light street fires and throw stones at police; police return fire with rubber bullets. Injuries not known.

Economic Freedom Fighters supporters accused supported of ANC of assaulting them outside a police station in Diepsloot. The attacks are believed to be sparked by the tension caused by the rape and murder of two young girls in a nearby slum.
Service delivery protesters demonstrate in Port Elizabeth.
Cookhouse residents burnt tires and blocked roads to express their dissatisfaction with the rate of housing delivery and other services.
Two protesters are killed and seven injured, allegedly by eThekwini Municipality security guards, in a fight over electricity usage.
Mthonjaneni Municipality staff protest in front of a Mthonjaneni government building against the mayor, who they say is corrupt.
Three alleged robbers were stoned to death at a tavern by vigilante customers after the trio were allegedly poised to rob the venue.
The bodies of two men are discovered by police in the Philippi section of Cape Town, the victims of suspected vigilante justice.
Bekkersdal residents went on a rampage during a protest, throwing stones at the police, and destroying and looting a building.

A group of Bekkersdal residents riot in service delivery protest to the nearby Simunye township. Police fired rubber bullets in response. A man was later found dead, though police do not believe the death was a result of the protest.

Supporters of Agang SA gather in protest outside a Pretoria court where five men were to appear for the rape and murder of two toddlers in Diepsloot. Earlier in the week Diepsloot residents rioted in protest of the crime.
Members of the Gauteng Education Department gather in protest-hit Bekkersdal to protect matrics writing exams under government administration.

Three people, allegedly Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) members, were arrested after protesters threw faeces at Sanlams head office in Cape Town. The group was protesting sanitation services in the area. One of the protesters is believed to have assaulted a police officer.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: About 50 shop stewards from the South African Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) protested outside the Cape Town Civic Centre, demanding one of their colleagues be reinstated after he was fired for the unauthorised use of an official City of Cape Town vehicle.
Angry residents have burned down a house in Cookhouse, Eastern Cape for unknown reason. When police attempted to disperse the crowd the crown pelted them with stones. Causalities not known.
A group of about 40 students set piles of tires alight in Bekkersdal in protest of an educational issue. Police dispersed the students and ordered them back to school.

Looters run amok in downtown Cape town after a 3,500 strong protest becomes violent. The reason for the protest is believed to be related to sanitation. Police were on the scene, but did not engage the rioters. The riot lasted nearly seven hours.
On or around 31 October 0213, two Bangladeshi nationals killed in Kgetleng. Xenophobic attitudes of a group of locals are the suspected motive.

ANC supporters gather to protest the opening of the Saldanha Bay industrial development zone and to prevent Western Cape Premier Helen Zille from speaking at the inauguration. It is not clear why the ANC protested this event.

A 12-year-old boy is shot in the head by police attempting to disperse a group gathered to protest in Jabulani, Soweto. The boy was taken to the hospital and is expected to survive. Residents demanded that speed humps be erected on roads, as cars were driving at high speed in the area.
Employees of a hospital protest for a salary increase. Exact date of the event is vague.
Residents of a burning building block attack fire-fighters when they felt they were not extinguishing the flames quickly enough.
A vigilante group beat a 65-year old man to death for allegedly stealing sheep.
A vigilante mob kills six suspected members of a criminal street gang, burning several of the victims alive. The vigilante group throw stones at police, who were trying to restore order to the area.
A vigilante mob kills six suspected members of a criminal street gang, burning several of the victims alive. The vigilante group throw stones at police, who were trying to restore order to the area.

Police open fire on a group of EFF protesters situated outside the Union Buildings. It is unclear what the EFF was specifically protesting at the time of the shooting. Several other members of the EFF were arrested following retaliatory clashes. Ten injured. The clash took place along the R55 linking Pretoria and Sandton after their buses were blocked from leaving the informal settlement. The police later released a statement saying the march was illegal because no permission had been granted in advance, denying clashes were politically driven. It is unclear why the group was protesting, though the party typically calls for a repatriation of white owned land.
Residents protest against ongoing taxi turf violence.

A vigilante mob lynches a suspected rapist. Police arrest three after a larger group, continuation to be upset over suspicions of rape in their community, threaten to burn a police station due to lax security.

A vigilante mob lynches a suspected rapist. Police arrest three after a larger group, continuation to be upset over suspicions of rape in their community, threaten to burn a police station due to lax security. Several members of the mob were later arrested.
Following clashes with police days earlier, members of the EFF stage another protest without incident.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Members of the South African National Civic Organisation (Sanco) and South African Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) blockaded roads and forced shops to close during a service delivery protest.
UDF members burn their utility bills outside of municipal offices in Mitchells Plain in a protest against the city of Cape Town.
Hindu leaders, politicians and community leaders gathered outside the Sunday Times offices in Overport, Durban, to protest over the depiction of Hindu deity Ganesha in a cartoon.
A police officer is shot and killed at his home in Malelane for unknown reason.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU protests e-tolling along the M1 highway.
Madibeng residents protest in Pretoria for better roads in their community.

column7: BAWSI: Black Association of the Wine and Spirit Industry
column17: Striking, picketing members of BAWSI assault management of a wine firm, destroy company and civilian property.
Residents of slum dwellings levelled a piece of land along Kamesh Road in Uitenhage, burning tires and throwing rubbish in protest after housing promises were not met by the government.
Phetanenge village residents outside Tzaneen block roads to schools in protest of service delivery.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: SAMWU union members embark on a service delivery protest in Port Saint Johns, blocking roads and lighting fires.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of COSATU protest in several location in and around Cape Town metro, including the city centre, calling for a national strike against e-tolling, labour brokers, and private management or ownership of toll roads.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of COSATU protest in several location in and around Cape Town metro, including the city centre, calling for a national strike against e-tolling, labour brokers, and private management or ownership of toll roads.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Cosatu-affiliated union members who marched in Durbans CBD to voice their displeasure against the e-tolls, labour brokers and the youth wage subsidy.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of COSATU protest in several location in and around Cape Town metro, including the city centre, calling for a national strike against e-tolling, labour brokers, and private management or ownership of toll roads.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of COSATU protest in several location in and around Cape Town metro, including the city centre, calling for a national strike against e-tolling, labour brokers, and private management or ownership of toll roads.

A bomb exploded in Johannesburg during the afternoon hours afternoon, leaving 2 dead and five injured. The official cause of the blast is yet to be determined though authorities speculate it may have been detonated by shop owner facing extradition to his country in Europe where he is facing a prison sentence.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of COSATU protest in several location in and around Cape Town metro, including the city centre, calling for a national strike against e-tolling, labour brokers, and private management or ownership of toll roads.

Dozens of protesters gathered outside a platinum mine to demand employment. Security at the Mogalakwena Mine fired warning shots to disperse the crowd of about 100 people that went on a rampage, blocking roads and stoning company vehicles.

Three houses and two taverns have been set alight by angry residents in the Setlagole area outside Mahikeng. The structures belonged to people accused of kidnapping a seven-year-old boy on November 1, and community members were upset no one had yet been arrested.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Scores of Cosatu members gather throughout Johannesburg to protest against e-tolls and labour brokers.

column16: Daily Dispatch (South Africa); South African Press Association
column17: Housing protesters burn tires and loot shops at Langa station. Two councilors are severely assaulted during the demonstrations
Nine housing protesters are arrested when they became violent at Langa station.

Residents took to the streets, barricaded roads, looted shops and threw rocks a passer-bys after police and Red Ants militia went to Imbeliseni informal settlement looking for illegal electricity connections. Three were arrested and charged with public violence.
Residents of several shanty towns protest service delivery along several points along the N2 in Western Cape. Exact date vague.
Residents of several shanty towns protest service delivery along several points along the N2 in Western Cape. Exact date vague.
Residents of several shanty towns protest service delivery along several points along the N2 in Western Cape. Exact date vague.
Residents of several shanty towns protest service delivery along several points along the N2 in Western Cape. Exact date vague.
Residents of several shanty towns protest service delivery along several points along the N2 in Western Cape. Exact date vague.
A group of residents throw stones at a police cruiser without provocation. One person arrested.

A protesting group set fire to an excavator and threw stones at a truck during a protest at a construction site over the appointment of a unfavourable contractor. Ten, including a ward councillor, are arrested and charged with public violence.
A xenophobic vigilante group attacks Zimbabwe residents in Liphalale town, where five shops, two houses and two vehicles belonging to Zimbabweans were burnt. No causalities reported.
A turf riot among taxi drivers routes grows into an assault of civilians when rioters suspect a group was taking photographs of the clash. No causalities reported.

A large group of Waterval residents burn down an elderly woman's home after suspecting her of bewitching bus drivers, causing them to crash along a nearby highway. When police arrived to calm the situation the mob began throwing stones at police. No causalities reported. In the following days 33 suspects were charged with arson.
Sex workers protest outside a Cape Town court where a man charged with killing a fellow worker is being tried for the crime.
Scores of informal traders and their supporters sang and waved placards outside the High Court in Johannesburg where their applications against the removal of their stalls will be heard.
A pilot flew above Johannesburg towing a banner critical of e-tolls.
A group of disabled protesters burn a wheelchair in front of the Rivonia e-toll customer service centre in protest of the toll.
A group of men gather in Kimberly to protest a recent string of violence against women in Northern Cape.
Following the eviction of residents of a housing facility many riot, burning structures and stoning police. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
Democratic Alliance supporters gathered at the Gauteng provincial legislature in Johannesburg to protest against e-tolling.

Street vendors and police officers clash after a court ruling against the traders is decided. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the group. An attorney representing the traders was arrested, and two others were reportedly injured.
Hundreds of protesters carrying banners made their way into the Cape Town International Convention Centre (CTICC), singing protest songs critical of the South African health care system.
A group beat a man with iron rods and threw stones at him, believing he was responsible for stabbing their friend. Several of the perpetrators were later arrested.
A ""top cop"" is assassinated at her home. The motive and perpetrator are unknown.

column9: MTMSA: Movement for the Transformation of Media in South Africa
column17: Right2Know protesters gather outside Independent Newspapers offices in St Georges Mall to demonstrate against the firing of an editor. The group also called for greater press freedom and greater editorial independence. During the protest MTMSA counter protesters gathered, calling for a ""media transformation"" and accusing the R2K group of racism. The MTMSA is an umbrella group mainly comprised of Agang SA supporters. Clashes reported, though the extent of them are not clear. Police intervene and dispersed the two groups.
Residents of Soshanguve march in protest, demanding the city of Tshwane be responsible for repairs caused by a hail storm several months ago.
A group ransacks several Somali owned shops the day after a Somali business owner shot and killed a seven-year-old boy in error. No injuries reported.

Residents of Bronkhorstspruit protest against the arrest if a local on Christmas Day. Several protesters were arrested by police for public violence - a road in the Dark City township had been blocked by burning tires and sticks. The reason for the initial arrest is not known.

Residents of Bronkhorstspruit protest for a second day over the arrest of a fellow resident on 25/12. The demonstrators had planed to march to Ekangala police station on to demand the release of other residents arrested while protesting the previous day. Several other arrests were reported after the group became violent and blocked a road. Details of the violence is not known.

A rioting mob looted and smashed the windows of a truck shop in Wiggins near Cato Manor (Durban) after a man was found dead with his body protruding through the burglar guards of the shop early in the day. The mob blamed the owner of the shop, a Mozambican, for his death. It is not clear if the store owner was harmed.

A former head of Rwandas external intelligence service and prominent members of the RNC was found strangled in a hotel in South Africa, where he has lived in exile for several years. It is believed the assassinated by agents of (Rwandan President Paul) Kagame. It is not clear if the crime was committed on 31/12 or 01/01/13.
A group of Krugersdorp residents protest mining activity in the area, believing it was destroying their houses. Reports of shots fired, one arrest reported.

Krugersdorp residents protest mining activity in their area for a second day. Many roads on the area were blocked with burning tires and stones. The situation was calm on the third day, though many area streets remained blocked.

Dozens of people, most of them wearing pink T-shirts, gathered outside the Brakpan Magistrates Court ahead of the appearance of a man accused of raping and killing his four-year-old niece. The group was demanding a reinstitution of the death penalty.
Street vendors attack police after an officer shot and killed a fellow vendor during a botched arrest.

A group of street hawkers protest outside a Pretoria court during a hearing for a fellow vendor charged with public violence for battling police officers after the killing of a fellow trader during a botched arrest. Several protesters threw stones at nearby police officer and looted a passing food cart. It is reported that a number of protesters filled the courtroom during the hearing.

ANC supporters and members protest an Economic Freedom Fighters event in Nkandla. The reason for the protest is not clear, though it is known the EFF group was constructing low-cost housing structures near a residence of President Zuma (ANC).
A group of animal rights activists protest a travelling circus.
Service delivery protesters demonstrate against poor water supply.
Following the destruction of shacks by metro police, residents, numbering 100, protested the destruction in the streets, burning tries and throwing stones at passing cars. No injuries reported.

Four service delivery protesters are shot; two dead, in Brits, outside Pretoria. The one of the wounded later dies in hospital. The demonstrators, protesting poor water supply in the area, which had been out for a week, gathered for a second day of demonstrations. Though the protests were described as ""violent"", some witnesses claim police brutality. Later, it was learned that one of the deaths occurred after police pushed a protesters out of a moving vehicle. Several labour unions condemned the killings.

Parents of pupils attending Ntji Ga-Mothapo Primary in Ramogale outside Polokwane protest alleged disrespect from members of the facility over two consecutive days. The parents called for the removal of three of the teachers.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry.
Unidentified persons burn down a police officers home. The arson may have been revenge for earlier police work. No injury reported.
Service delivery protesters demonstrate against poor water supply for a third consecutive day. No report of violence or police involvement.

Parents of pupils attending Ntji Ga-Mothapo Primary in Ramogale outside Polokwane protest alleged disrespect from members of the facility over two consecutive days. The parents called for the removal of three of the teachers.
A street trader is shot and killed by police for unknown reasons.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry.

Train services to Mabopane north of Pretoria were interrupted due to a service delivery protest in the area. The group blocked Metrorail railway lines to Mabopane with rocks, and burning tyres, and damaged Metrorail signalling equipment such as cables, signals and signal boxes.

A Valhalla Park, ANC-backed service delivery and housing protest descends into violence. Police fired water cannons and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Four arrested, charged with public violence.

On 15 January 2014, about 50 foreign nationals were attacked by South African nationals with pangas, knives, steel pipes and sticks in the Jika Joe informal settlement, Pietermaritzburg (KwaZulu-Natal) after the body of a South African national was found dead in the settlement. [size=no report]

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry.
Soshanguve residents protest forces eviction from their homes over two consecutive days. It is not clear why the residents were evicted.

A member of Madibeng Mayoral Committee (MMC) is attacked at a memorial service for three people killed in a recent violent protest in Mothutlung, Brits. The assailant is unknown, but it is speculated he may hold sympathies with water protesters. The politician suffered minor injuries.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry.
A PAC leader, Lesoana Makhanda, is shot and killed at his home in Walkerville, south of Johannesburg during the morning hours. The party believes the act was a ""well-orchestrated assassination"".
A vigilante group kills five men for unknown reasons during the evening hours.
Soshanguve residents protest forces eviction from their homes over two consecutive days. It is not clear why the residents were evicted.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry.
The Waterberg ANC secretary is abducted and attack by three armed men around 9pm when he was coming out of a shop. He was released the following day. The motive for the attack is not known.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry. Six reported dead over several days.

Residents of the Princess informal settlement embark on multiple consecutive days of service delivery and housing protests against the local government in Roodeport. The group blocked roads and reportedly threw stones at passing cars in the fourth day. On the fifth day protesters attacked the home and family of a local resident, looting the house of their property. The group may have shown violent action in the sixth and seventh days, though this fact is not clear. The Right2Know was publicly supportive of the protest action, though it is unclear if they or their supporters were present during the demonstrations. The protesters vowed to continue protests until their ""promised"" houses were built. Calm was reached on the final day with a promise for housing from the appropriate government ministry. Six reported dead over several days.

Residents of Durban Deep informal settlement protest violently poor service delivery; throwing stones and lighting fires. Police disperse the group with rubber bullets, one protester shot dead and fifteen arrested. It was later learned the death was caused by illegal live ammunition, causing a scandal which led to four police arrests and the suspension of others.

Residents of Hebron, near Ga-Rankuwa outside Brits in Pretoria begin a march to Madibeng Local Municipality in protest of poor service delivery. They are complaining about service delivery in the township on the border between North West and Gauteng provinces. Adding to the protesters were mourners of a man killed by police in a earlier, similar protest in the area.

City of Cape Town employees and contract cleaning staff were pelted with stones and faeces by Barcelona informal settlement residents angry they city had not provided cleaning services in their area for an extended period.
Nearly 40 Right2Know supporters gathered outside the Cape Town CCMA offices to protest the dismissal of a newspaper editor.
About 50 Durban Deep residents marched in protest to the Roodepoort Magistrates Court to attend the court appearance of 15 arrested protesters from earlier events.

Residents of Relela Village, outside Tzaneen riot after a murder suspect was released from jail following questioning. The protesters burned several houses, armed themselves with petrol bombs and stones, and attacked the local police at the station. When police confronted the rioters a fifteen year old, as well as two other unidentified persons were shot and killed, allegedly by police. 15 officers were injured, three critically and 19 police vehicles were damaged during the confrontation while nine people were arrested for public violence. The following day the police confirmed two at fault deaths. Conflicting reports hold that three deaths were reported.
A group of demonstrators gather in Bloemfontein to protest against e-tolls.
A group of demonstrators gather in Durban to protest against e-tolls.
A group of 300+ motorcycle riders gather in Keizersgracht in central Cape Town to protest against e-tolls.
A group of demonstrators gather in King Williams Town to protest against e-tolls.
A group of demonstrators gather in Port Elizabeth to protest against e-tolls.
Students of the Durban and Mangosuthu Universities of Technology in Durban protest, demanding more students be provided student aid from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme.

University of Johannesburg students protest financial shortages of the National Student Financial Scheme (NSFAS), a tuition assistance organization. Several of the students were suspended after it was reported they had disrupted administrative and registration activities during their protest. Additionally, the following day, several were arrested.

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: SASCO and Tshwane University of Technology students protest the actions of the National Student Financial Aid Scheme, whos recent student payout was less than expected. There were reports that many of students threw stones, intentionally damaging school property.
Scores of women protested outside the Bellville Magistrates Court ahead of a bail application of a man charged with raping a nine-year-old girl.
A group protests poor job opportunities at a mine in Masilo at Theunissen, 23 arrested over two days of protest.
Service delivery protesters burn cars in the Sea View area, off the N2. Precise date of the protest vague.

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: For the second day, SASCO and Tshwane University of Technology students protest the actions of the National Student Financial Aid Scheme, whos recent student payout was less than expected. Reports of stones being thrown at university property. Security personnel fired rubber bullets and paintballs, driving the students off the campus. The protest continued with fire-starting riots the following day.
IFP block chairman killed at KwaMashu Hostel; 1 other killed in same incident
A group protests poor job opportunities at a mine in Masilo at Theunissen, 23 arrested over two days of protest.

Pupils and their parents of a Durban area school become violent in a protest against a court order that returned twelve teachers who have been accused of sexual misconduct back to the classroom. The group stoned cars, hurled rubbish and sprayed teachers with a hosepipe. They made verbal threats before being dispersed by public order police.

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: Backed by SASCO, students of the Tshwane University of Technology riot, burning tires outside the entrance gate in protest of the actions of the National Student Financial Aid Scheme, which did not pay students what they had promised. The groups further demands included ""an end to racism in Afrikaner-dominated faculties, readmission of all academically excluded students, provision for adequate residential accommodation, and salary cuts for all senior managers and directors."" No injuries reported.
National Student Financial Aid Scheme protesters demonstrate on three of TUTs Pretoria area campuses, demanding students go home and that all learning cease until their demands have been met.
National Student Financial Aid Scheme protesters demonstrate on three of TUTs Pretoria area campuses, demanding students go home and that all learning cease until their demands have been met.
Residents stage violent service delivery protests, setting a police station alight. No report of arrest or injury.
National Student Financial Aid Scheme protesters demonstrate on three of TUTs Pretoria area campuses, demanding students go home and that all learning cease until their demands have been met.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union rejected a wage offer from three platinum companies, stage a protest to express their unhappiness with the offer.
Service delivery riots continue into a second day. Residents again attack a police station as well as a municipal office. No reported injuries.
Residents of the Joe Slovo informal settlement in Milnerton blocked roads in a service delivery protest on 31/01.
Students violently protested when foreign students were not allowed to register at the Central University of Technology

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: SAMWU stage a violent demonstration after an impasse between the union and municipal executives.
On 1 February 2014, several shops owned by Somali nationals were looted by a group in Pienaar (Mpumalanga) after a man was killed by a shop owner. [size=no report]

About 100 people were protesting in Honingklip, near Krugersdorp in the West Rand over poor service delivery. The protesters, who began their demo in the morning hours, blocked roads with bricks and stones. Two reported injuries. The nature of the injuries are not clear.
Residents protesting against high water bills set a police station, two trucks and a municipal building alight.
Main Reef Road in Johannesburg is blocked off to traffic on the afternoon of 01/02 due to ""violent protest."" The nature of the protest is not known.
Water customers continue a protest against high billing. No report of violence.
Protesters in Zandspruit, near Honeydew, were throwing stones at cars, resulting in the closure of Beyers Naude Drive. The protesters were demanding better government service deliver.
Water customers continue a protest against high billing. No report of violence.
Hundreds of taxi operators carried placards insulting President Jacob Zuma at a march against e-tolls in Pretoria on 03/02.
On 3 February 2014, more than 16 foreign-owned shops were looted in Duduza (Gauteng) after residents were informed that a child was shot and killed by a foreign national. [size=no report]
Students violently protested when foreign students were not allowed to register at the Central University of Technology

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Police fired stun grenades to disperse protesting SAMWU municipal workers outside the East London City Hall. The protesters responded by throwing stones at the police. Two police officers were reportedly injured, six arrests reported.

Residents protesting against high water bills loot foreign owned businesses in the Rethabiseng and Zithobeni areas near Bronkhorstspruit during the early morning hours. Additionally, library and house in Zithobeni were totally gutted by arsonists later in the afternoon. 31 arrests reported.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: South African police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse about 3,000 ""violent"" striking miners near Rustenburg. According to police, ""Strikers carrying dangerous weapons, such as knobkerries and sticks, blocked the road and were threatening to remove non-striking workers at the shaft."" Two protesters arrested.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Striking SAMWU members ransack a government billing office in Chiselhurst, destroying computers. The group also ransacked another Buffalo City Meto government building in either the downtown area or East London area.
Residents of Boiketlong, Sebokeng burn tyres and clash with police during a protest poor housing and service delivery. During the protest a 26-year-old demonstrator is shot dead by police.

Residents of Sebokeng hold a lengthy protest over poor services. As the demonstrations wore on the protesters divided into two camps. One group wanted to remove police barricades on the road and the other group would not allow it. Several shots were fired between the groups. Police reportedly shot and killed a demonstrator in an effort to disperse the two groups.

Residents of Sebokeng hold a lengthy protest over poor services. As the demonstrations wore on the protesters divided into two camps. One group wanted to remove police barricades on the road and the other group would not allow it. Several shots were fired between the groups. Police reportedly shot and killed a demonstrator in an effort to disperse the two groups.

Action Campaign protested against ""pharmagate"" at drug company Boehringer Ingelheims offices in Johannesburg. The protesters believed the American company was attempting to lobby on behalf of changing existing SA drug law.
A protest erupts in Ekangala over the high price of electricity. Exact date of protest not clear.

Protesters demanding lower electricity prices burn down several buildings east of the capital, Pretoria. According to a police report, demonstrators set a clinic, a hall and a house on fire in the Bronkhorstspruit district. There were no reported injuries. There was a similar protest the previous day in the area.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Striking SAMWU members violently protest. Dissatisfied over a municipal wage offer, the union burnt garbage in the street, and attempted to burn down Buffalo City Hall. Firefighters quickly responded and managed to extinguish the fire and about 30 protesters were arrested for public violence. About five protesters were injured during clashes with police and were taken to hospital.

Violence in Sir Lowrys Pass Village, as an early morning protest over a new Temporary Relocation Area (TRA) became a running battle between protesters and police. Protesters burnt tyres, blocked roads and threw stones at police who responded with water cannon, stun grenades, tear gas canisters and rubber bullets. One protester arrested.

On 6 February 2014, residents, angry at foreign nationals operating in the Majakaneng area, demonstrators torched three vehicles and a councillors house. A foreign-owned shop owner reportedly was injured. Police dispersed the group. [size=no report]
Water customers continue a protest against high billing. No report of violence.
Residents of Sebokeng protest the local APC led government after service delivery protester was shot and killed by police the previous day. The protesters believe police forces are an arm of the APC.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of FAWU stage a protest march to Johannesburgs central police station to demand a 32 year-old murder investigation be reopened.
NUM members march in protest outside the Mining Indaba, a mining investment event in Cape Town. Police stopped and dispersed the marchers.

A man died when South African police and security guards fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters at an Anglo American Platinum mine near Rustenburg. It is not clear if the protesters were acting violently. Earlier in the week, police dispersed around 3,000 ""violent"" striking miners who had been blocking roads and threatening non-strikers.

A mineworker at Swartklip Union mine in Limpopo is shot dead by police using live ammunition while the group protested during a labour strike. The protesters had barricaded a road with burning tires and rocks. Following the gunfire the group clashed with police.
Residents of Uitenhage hold a service delivery protest. Exact day of the protest is vague.
Residents protest violently over poor housing, setting fires in the streets. The mayor of the town promised to address the protesters grievances.
Protesters barricade roads in Hebron demanding the government provide them improving housing.

Residents of Boiketlong, Sebokeng protest poor service delivery in their settlements. The groups formed a human chain in an attempt to stop police from entering their neighbourhoods. Residents were singing 'siya shaya' (we beat you up) and burnt debris in the road. A similar protest two days prior led to the fatal shooting of a demonstrator by police.

About 50 protesters descended on Khayamandi High School during the morning hours in a bid to prevent people from registering to vote by threatening them with death, and threatened to burn down the school. The protesters threw rocks and stones at the police, who retaliated by firing rubber bullets, eventually managing to disperse the crowd. The stand-off came after what protesters said was a snub by Premier Helen Zille when they had demanded to meet her on Friday.

Petrol bombs were thrown at two voter registration stations in Bekkersdal on the West Rand by a group of marching protesters. Additionally, it was reported that many of the protesters threw stones and threatened to kill anyone who registered to vote. The protesters were angered by politicians of all parties that their service delivery need have not been met despite years promises. A number of people were arrested in the area. No injuries reported.
Isiqalo informal settlement residents protest poor service delivery.

Three protesters are arrested during violent clashes with the police in Mitchells Plain, where residents of the Isiqalo informal settlement barricaded a main road with rocks, burning tyres and rubbish in protest of poor service delivery. The protest began the previous day.

Anti-election protesters from the Siqala informal settlement shut a large section of Vanguard Drive during the morning hours. Protesters burned tires, toyi-toyied and removed party election posters from lamp posts. They also dumped faeces from portaloos on the road. A protest leader stated, ""the ANC and the DA had both failed to bring meaningful improvements to his life since the advent of democracy.""

Students lead protest of two UKZN campuses in the Durban area, Westville and Edgewood (Pinetown). The university was not aware of the reason for the protests as there had been no communication from students with university management. Four protesters were arrested at the Edgewood campus.

Students lead protest of two UKZN campuses in the Durban area, Westville and Edgewood (Pinetown). The university was not aware of the reason for the protests as there had been no communication from students with university management. Four protesters were arrested at the Edgewood campus.
A mob of men kill two Zimbabweans in Thohoyandou. The motive may have been xenophobic in nature. The exact date of the attack is not entirely clear.
DA supporters gather outside ANC headquarters building to protest against the party.
Stranded over-the-road bus travellers protest outside the company offices, demanding refunds after poor service.

Students from Buffalo City Public FET College clashed with police during a staged sit-in from campus housing at the institutions East London main campus hall. Police used a water cannon and threw stun grenades to disperse the large crowd, causing students to respond with violence.

A DA march for jobs becomes chaotic after police stop the group from marching near Luthuli House, the ANC headquarters, in an effort to avoid violence between the two groups. At the nearby Luthuli House ANC members openly brandished stones, bricks, sticks, knobkieries and sjamboks as they toyi-toyied, chanting anti-DA and anti-Helen Zille songs and slogans, in an effort to anger the DA marchers. Police tear gassed the ANC members, who responded by throwing Molotov cocktails and bricks at police, who were seen as protecting members of the Democratic Alliance. Several DA protesters had gathered near the Luthuli House the evening before. Three arrests, no reported causalities.

A DA march for jobs becomes chaotic after police stop the group from marching near Luthuli House, the ANC headquarters, in an effort to avoid violence between the two groups. At the nearby Luthuli House ANC members openly brandished stones, bricks, sticks, knobkieries and sjamboks as they toyi-toyied, chanting anti-DA and anti-Helen Zille songs and slogans, in an effort to anger the DA marchers. Police tear gassed the ANC members, who responded by throwing Molotov cocktails and bricks at police, who were seen as protecting members of the Democratic Alliance. Several DA protesters had gathered near the Luthuli House the evening before. Three arrests, no reported causalities.

On 12 February 2014, a teenager was shot and injured during clashes between foreign nationals and locals in Botleng, near Delmas (Mpumalanga). Clashes started as locals complained about unemployment in the area. ANC offices were set on fire. [size=no report]

On 13 February 2014, clashes between foreign nationals and locals in Botleng, near Delmas (Mpumalanga) were registered for the second day. Clashes started as locals complained about unemployment in the area. [size=no report]
A group of pensioners, who had been waiting the a series of queues at Home Affairs office protest the delay.

More than 2 000 supporters of former ANC councillor Loyiso Nkohla, also a leader of the so-called ""poo protesters"", blocked traffic throughout Cape Towns city centre as they marched to the Western Cape High Court in protest of a court ruling of misconduct against him. The police tried to redirect the protesters on to the pavements in town, but failed. Instead the group marched in Loop Street, Wale Street, Adderley Street and Strand Street, blocking the roads as they made their way to the Cape Town station to take taxis and buses home.
NFP members Nomusa Nhlengana, 31, and Zama Zungu, are shot and injured when they cross paths with IFP members
Video circulated of man being beaten to death; police confirmed location and time later; some in crowd are wearing ANC shirts
About 100 marchers from Delft's Tsunami informal settlement protested on the N2 Gateway housing project during morning hours, claiming corruption in the allocation of new units.

Nine people were arrested for public violence during a service delivery protest in Mabopane, north of Pretoria. Mothutsane said residents were protesting against the lack of toilets and a proper sewerage system. The nature of their violence is not known.
A councillors house in Mahlongwa, Umkomazi was set alight and cars, including a police vehicle, were stoned during service delivery protests.
NFP branch leader at KwaMashu Hostel shot dead by gunmen
Service delivery protests become violent in the Meadowlands area during the early morning hours of 18/02. Police quelled the situation, but rioting renewed during the evening hours.
A group of people pelt motorists with stones for unknown reason near or in Soweto.

A anti-demolition protest in the Zandspruit informal settlement near Honeydew. Protesters lit fires and poured rubble onto the road to stop demolition crew from entering their settlement. Part of Beyers Naude Drive was closed due to the protests. The protest continued into the next day. No reported injuries or arrest.

On 18 February 2014, foreign-owned shops were looted and destroyed in Cullinan, Tshwane (Gauteng), following the death of a young suspected thief at the hands of a Pakistani shop owner. One Pakistani national fired shots at the rioters, injuring several. Four people were arrested. [size=at least 4]
Violent service delivery protests renew for a second day in the Meadowlands area. One reported death.

On 19 February 2014, police fired stunt grenades to disperse demonstrators in Cullinan, Tshwane (Gauteng). The police were escorting foreign shop owners out of the city after a mob attacked several people the day prior, after a child was shot by a Pakistani. [size=no report]
A anti-demolition protest in the Zandspruit informal settlement continues for a second day. No arrests reported.

Striking University of KwaZulu-Natal students (Howard College Campus) ""violently"" protest. 26 arrests reported. It is believed the students were on strike due to student fees. Police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse them.
IFP Womens Brigade member at KwaMashu Hostel is shot and killed by unknown group
Following the arrest of several Howard College protesters, several of the remaining group marched to the Umbilo police station to demand their release.

Striking University of KwaZulu-Natal students riot - burning bins and throwing stones at the police. Many of the students also attacked a lecturer who they pushed her to the floor and stamped on her. The economics lecturer from the Westville Campus was accosted after she told a group of striking students that she refused to be bullied by them. She was rescued by two of her students who escorted her from the lecture room.

On 23 February 2014, five Chinese-owned shops were looted and set on fire by a group in Moletlane (Limpopo) after a man was stabbed to death during an argument with a Chinese shop owner. 63 people were arrested. [size=at least 63]
Protesters blocked roads in Boksburg with burning tires and rocks during the early morning hours. Police were not yet sure who was responsible for the protest or the reason for it.
Dozens of Tshwane community health care workers recently marched in central Pretoria to demand the Gauteng Department of Health pay overdue stipends. Date not clear.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA members protest outside the Parliament building, demanding for better jobs for black youth.
DA supporters protest outside Uganda High Commission in Pretoria against a Ugandan law outlawing homosexual behaviour. Police made several arrests, citing illegal protesting.

Protesters blocked Chris Hani Road in Pimville, Soweto, during the evening hours with burning tyres and rocks. Police dispersed the crowd, but made no arrest. It is believe the group was protesting over pre-paid water notices.

Seskhona Peoples Rights Movement gathered in the central business district around 8.30am to march to the provincial legislature against poor service delivery. Police dispersed the group with water cannon and made twelve arrests.

On 27 February 2014, about 400 residents of Setlagole burned tires on the N18 freeway, between Vryburg and Mahikeng (North-West), in a demonstration to demand a feedback from the mayor on issues pertaining to the memorandum they handed in on 14 February 2014. The police used rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the group. Foreign-owned shops were looted. 20 people were arrested. [size=about 400]
Service delivery protesters again amass in Pimville for a second consecutive day, blocking roads. Police made no arrests.
Police fire tear gas to disperse a group of road-blocking protesters near the town of Brits. The reason for the protest is not known. One reported death of a small child, possibly due to the gas.
On 2 March 2014, residents looted Somali-owned shops in Pienaar (Mpumalanga). 21 people were arrested. [size=at least 21]
Sex workers and sex worker advocates in Durban, Polokwane, Cape Town and Johannesburg took to the streets to honour International Sex Worker Rights Day.

A group of students protest after it is learned that several of their teachers contracts would not be renewed for the upcoming school year. The pupils barricaded the school gate and prevented acting principal Isaac Shadung and the remaining teachers from entering the school premises until the contracts of the six teachers were renewed ""on a permanent basis"".
Sex workers and sex worker advocates in Durban, Polokwane, Cape Town and Johannesburg took to the streets to honour International Sex Worker Rights Day.
Sex workers and sex worker advocates in Durban, Polokwane, Cape Town and Johannesburg took to the streets to honour International Sex Worker Rights Day.
A residential militia stone a suspected rapist to death.
Sex workers and sex worker advocates in Durban, Polokwane, Cape Town and Johannesburg took to the streets to honour International Sex Worker Rights Day.
About 500 protesters gathered outside the offices of the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries calling for the reinstatement of the man who presided over a controversial court decision.

Exiled former Rwandan generals house in South Africa attacked by suspected Rwandan political opposition. The general, who was not home at the time of the attack, is of the RNC. The location of his house within South Africa was not revealed.
About 80 members of SPRM, an arm of the APC, are blocked from protesting outside a Cape Town train station by police. The group was picketing at court ruling made against their leader.
Service delivery protests in Bushbuckridge, as well as ""other areas"". Specific location not known.
Service delivery protests in Hazywiew, Mbomblea, as well as ""other areas"". Protesters barricaded roads in Hazyview
Members of the EFF march in Pretoria, carrying signs with anti-Zuma slogans. A protester died during the demonstration, apparently of some kind of trip-and-fall accident.
Service delivery protests in Tshwete, as well as ""other areas"". Specific location not known.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Members of AMCU marched in Pretoria around the noon hour, accusing the government, including President Zuma, of colluding with platinum firms to try and break an ongoing strike. Police were present, but did not engage the protesters.
A group of angry residents of Soshanguve Block G, Pretoria, hoisted banners and posters to express dissatisfaction with their local councillor.
About 1000 people staged a service delivery protest on the N14 highway.

On or around 7 March 2014, South African police beat a Nigerian national ""mercilessly"" for unknown reason. The date of the incident is unclear. The Nigerian embassy in Pretoria has ""sent a strongly-worded note to the Department of Foreign Affairs of South Africa protesting the attack and demanding that the perpetrators be brought to justice"".
A group protests a gay pride event, expressing they do not believe the group planning the event raises issues concerning most LBGT communities in South Africa.
Two men were arrested for public violence and intimidation in Nomlacu near Bizana, after a service delivery protest. The youths involved in the protest were arrested for throwing stones at police.
Local workers protest outside Egan Refinery demanding that the company provide more jobs to local residents. A security guard is assaulted after pulling his gun on the demonstrators.

column7: CAOSA: Concerned Arts Organisation of South Africa
column17: Members of CAOSA protest what they describe as the slow pace and lack of service they suffer at the hands of the National Lottery Distribution Trust Fund.

Protesting residents of Bekkersdal were forced to take cover after the bodyguards of ANC members fired several shots at them. Residents were violently protesting against the presence of the ANC political bosses in their township. Before the ANC leaders entered the township their police escort arrived, which was pelted with stones by the protesters. The police responded with rubber bullets and arrests. Causalities/injuries not known.

Protesting residents of Bekkersdal were forced to take cover after the bodyguards of ANC members fired several shots at them. Residents were violently protesting against the presence of the ANC political bosses in their township. Before the ANC leaders entered the township their police escort arrived, which was pelted with stones by the protesters. The police responded with rubber bullets and arrests. Causalities/injuries not known.

Residents of Joe Slovo Park informal settlement near Milnerton blockaded part of Freedom Way by burning tires and stoning the police after the City of Cape Towns Anti-Land Invasion Unit demolished over 100 shacks early yesterday.
Community members stoned and set alight a man accused of rape and witchcraft in an earlier case
University of the Western Cape students disrupted classes, damaged university property and obstructed traffic on campus

A group of taxi drivers held a protest near the Noord Street taxi rank in the Johannesburg CBD. The police arrived and dispersed the group with no reported incident. The reason for the protest is not clear.

A small gathering of protesters outside the buildings at Gallagher Park in Midrand, South Africa shouted ""AU where are you? Down, down, Ethiopia down!"" during the inauguration of the 10 years Anniversary of the Pan-African Parliament. The group, which was comprised of Ogaden-Somali and Oromo ethnic communities in Johannesburg, were mainly upset over Ethiopian human rights abuses.

Metrorail commuters stormed the rail service manager's offices at Cape Town Station to demand an end to poor train service. The Metrorail has recently been criticised to frequent scheduling delays, as well as unsafe station platforms.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: The NUMSA union marched to protest a new labour law it says will increase unemployment and poverty. Around 3,000 people wearing the unions trademark red t-shirts and berets marched in Johannesburgs Rosebank business centre. Unions and civic movements such as the Industries Workers Union of South Africa (Giwusa), the Soweto Electricity Crisis Campaign; Equal Education (EE) and Right 2 Know have partnered with Numsa on the campaign.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA protest at the Nongoza Jobe Hall in New Brighton against a new labour law that they believe is not in their interest. Unions and civic movements such as the Industries Workers Union of South Africa (Giwusa), the Soweto Electricity Crisis Campaign; Equal Education (EE) and Right 2 Know have partnered with Numsa on the campaign.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA protest a new labour law in Durban. Unions and civic movements such as the Industries Workers Union of South Africa (Giwusa), the Soweto Electricity Crisis Campaign; Equal Education (EE) and Right 2 Know have partnered with Numsa on the campaign.

A city bus is attacked by an unidentified group with wielding bricks and stones. After the driver and his eight passengers fled to safety the attackers set the bus alight. The motive for the attack is not known. No injuries reported.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA protest a new labour law in Cape Town. Unions and civic movements such as the Industries Workers Union of South Africa (Giwusa), the Soweto Electricity Crisis Campaign; Equal Education (EE) and Right 2 Know have partnered with Numsa on the campaign.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA protest a new labour law in Bloemfontein. Unions and civic movements such as the Industries Workers Union of South Africa (Giwusa), the Soweto Electricity Crisis Campaign; Equal Education (EE) and Right 2 Know have partnered with Numsa on the campaign.
Service delivery protests take place in Landsdowne, alone Baden Powell and Sheffield Road.
A SPRM led protest against the poor state of sanitation in the area leads to violence and 15 arrests. Protests took place in several areas around the city.

Residents of Bekela informal settlement near Phillipi protest poor service delivery during the early morning hours. Protesters burned tires and erected roadblocks. Police responded with stun grenades. At least one arrest reported.
Service delivery protest erupts in the Delft area of Mitchells Plain. No incidents reported.
ANC members threw stones at a bus carrying DA members and supporters during a Human Rights Day rally. The rally was marred by other violent protests as well.

A Human Rights Day rally is marred by violent protests from members of the (EFF) Economic Freedom Fighters and the (PAC) Pan-Africanist Congress, both of whom threw rocks when President Zuma took to a stage. Nearby, ANC members threw stones at a bus carrying DA members and supporters.

A Human Rights Day rally is marred by violent protests from members of the (EFF) Economic Freedom Fighters and the (PAC) Pan-Africanist Congress, both of whom threw rocks when President Zuma took to a stage. Nearby, ANC members threw stones at a bus carrying DA members and supporters.
Service delivery protests led by the SPRM take place in Cape Town and nearby Lwandle along the N2. The protests in Lwandle reportedly became violent, resulting in several arrests.
Service delivery protests led b y the SPRM take place in Cape Town and nearby Lwandle along the N2. The protests in Lwandle reportedly became violent, resulting in several arrests.
Hundreds of caregivers marched to the ANCs Luthuli House headquarters and the Department of Health offices in central Joburg, claiming they had not been paid for the past six months.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Striking teachers march to protest against missed pay and the education MEC.
A small girl is shot and wounded when police attempted to break up a service delivery protest in Lorraine.

On 26 March 2014, thirty five demonstrators were arrested for public violence, arson and malicious damage to property in Kanana, near Orkney. Demonstrators partially burnt the local municipality offices and pelted windows with stones. Others barricaded roads with burning tyres and looted a number of shops owned by foreign nationals. The rioting laster over two days. The reason for the demonstration is not clear. [size=at least 35]
A man was beaten to death by a vigilante mob after he was caught stealing a copper pipe in Kagiso.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: AMCU members protest for wage increases.

On 27 March 2014, thirty five demonstrators were arrested for public violence, arson and malicious damage to property in Kanana, near Orkney. Demonstrators partially burnt the local municipality offices and pelted windows with stones. Others barricaded roads with burning tyres and looted a number of shops owned by foreign nationals. The rioting laster over two days. The reason for the demonstration is not clear. [size=at least 35]
Service delivery protesters clash with police in Philippi. Police responded to the protesters, shooting stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the toyi-toying crowds as they gathered.
Groups of demonstrators sang and toyi-toyied outside the Bellville Magistrate's Court during the morning hours against the defendant in a rape trial.

Residents of Mamelodi East Extension 11 blocked the streets with burning tires and stones during the evening hours, demanding that the Tshwane municipality grant them permanent housing. The protest was reportedly peaceful.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: About 1,000 to 1,500 members of the National Education Health and Allied Workers Union marched through Cape Town during the morning hours, eventually to the offices of the Western Cape government.
Housing protests continue for a second day in Mamelodi, no incidents reported.
Residents of Mokgola village, near Zeerust, embark on a two day protest for water. Police remained nearby, but did not engage the protesters.
Two NUM shop members are attacked by unknown people the evening of 28/03. The reason for the assault is not known.
Residents of Mokgola village, near Zeerust, embark on a two day protest for water. Police remained nearby, but did not engage the protesters.
Former IFP member shot dead by unknown group at KwaMashu Hostel; another killed on same street soon after
A gay man is assaulted and raped by a group opposed to this homosexuality.
Residents torch a bus and block roads with burning tires over bus punctuality after a driver strike began.

A group of bus drivers strike and picketed outside the Dobsonville Piotrans Depot in Soweto and by the afternoon they were spotted sitting on pavements. The work stoppage caused commuters to riot in Hammanskraal.

About 500 residents of Clarke Estate blockaded 35th Street with burning tires and stones after law enforcement officers demolished the shack next to the council-owned Rooiberg Court flats. Two Cape Town law enforcement officers were injured, roads were closed, vehicles stoned and journalists attacked. Police responded with stun grenades, a water cannon and rubber bullets.
Around 70 fishermen protested for fishing permits outside the Hout Bay harbour. They blockaded the entrances and were alleged to have assaulted those who did have permits.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: About 100 workers dressed in Numsa T-shirts protested outside Johannesburg Scaffolding, threatening to burn down their trucks if they continued working and did not join the strike
Relatives and victims of the August 2012 Marikana killings staged a demonstration at the Farlam Commission of Inquiry after police lawyers asked that a witness be allowed to testify in camera.
Demonstrators gather along the N12 road to protest against several local elected officials, calling for their removal. The protest lasts over the course of several days.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Hundreds of members of labour union Amcu, wearing green shirts, descended on Melrose Arch in Johannesburg for a wage protest. Due to the protest, traffic surrounding the arch was disrupted for some time.
Demonstrators gather along the N12 road to protest against several local elected officials, calling for their removal. The protest lasts over the course of several days.
A group of ANC supporters threaten a DA party chair during a political news event and assault a television news crew.
Members of WASP and their allies protest near city hall against what they saw as broken labour promises by the mayor and city.

A Khayelitsha man was caught by a mob which beat him and then necklaced him (placing tires around the neck of the victim and setting them alight) in Enkanini informal settlement. The man, a suspected thief, was found in Baden Powell Drive. Residents at the scene said his accomplice had escaped.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Numbering 2,500 COSATU members block traffic near a toll gate in protest of high toll fees.
Demonstrators gather along the N12 road to protest against several local elected officials, calling for their removal. The protest lasts over the course of several days.
SACP members on marched in Pretoria to protest on the anniversary of the murder of their leader, Chris Hani.
Protesters call for the removal of several local public officials, including the mayor. It is not clear if there was any violence.

Three EFF election campaign events have allegedly been disrupted and sabotaged by ANC supporters, according to the EFF in Thokoza, Ekurhuleni. The disruption, which occurred during the early morning hours, involved the burning of its marquees and stage and sound systems.

Eldorado Park and Klipspruit West residents blocked roads and threw stones at passing cars during morning due to cable theft in the area. the two neighbouring communities were protesting along the K43 road as there was no power in the area.
On or around 5 April 2014, unidentified persons attacked businesses belonging to foreigners in the Maake area. It is not clear if there were any sustained injuries. Date(s) not entirely clear.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column9: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Cosatu affiliates attack each other with sticks and stones when it is realised each group had double-booked a speaker at a hotel conference.

Protesters torched the Lekwa-Teemane municipal office, community halls, and five houses belonging to the mayor, two councillors and two officials in the riot, the group calling for the removal of several public officials. Police make arrests, two police injured. Exact date of the violence vague. The protest has been ""ongoing since last week.""
Ofafa residents hold a protest over not have electricity for over 20 years. Date unknown: The protest was said to have occurred ""recently.""
Demonstrators protesting against elected officials continue to block the N12, damage private property.
Students at False Bay College in Khayelitsha shut down the university during a protest against money laundering they allege is occurring at the institution.
Demonstrators protesting against elected officials continue to block the N12, damage private property.
Demonstrators protesting against elected officials continue to block the N12, damage private property. A teenager is shot and killed by a shop owner because he was looting his shop.
An angry mob killed a man after he broke into a house in Phumola in Leondale on the East Rand. Police spokesman Captain Tsekiso Mofokeng said a group attacked a man after he was caught.

A protest by residents of Vlakfontein informal settlement, near Lenasia south of Johannesburg, has caused the closure of the Golden Highway during the evening hours. The protesters blocked roads and burned tires, upset by poor electricity service.
Violent Bloemhof protests continue. Demonstrators redouble their efforts after a shop owner shot a looter the previous day. Authorities call for calm.
Property destruction: Unidentified persons attack the home of a NUM leader under cover of night, burning it. No one was injured as the house was unoccupied at the time.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: Thousands of school pupils from various schools in Mamelodi in the east of Pretoria participated in a march in support of a schoolgirl allegedly raped by her teacher. The pupils, who were all dressed in school uniform, had handed a memorandum to police at the police station. The protest was coordinated by COSAS.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: Thousands of school pupils from various schools in Mamelodi in the east of Pretoria participated in a march in support of a schoolgirl allegedly raped by her teacher. The pupils, who were all dressed in school uniform, had handed a memorandum to police at the police station. The protest was coordinated by COSAS.
ANC supporters attack a DA campaign rally, DA supporters respond with force. Police separated the two groups. Injuries not known.
Suspected ANC poo protesters dump human faeces in suburban Rondebosch at the direction of party membership who called for protests to be extended into ""rich white suburbs.""
A group of women protest outside a court hearing of a man accused of murdering his girlfriend.
Residents protest in the Kiptown area of Soweto over poor services. Protesters claimed that if their demands are not reached in 16 days they would withhold rent.
Residents of Olievenhoutbosch in Centurion were protesting along the R55 for unknown reason. No violence reported. The group had dispersed later in the day.

On 15 April 2014, a 31-year-old man was assaulted and stabbed by residents of Tshelimnyama, near Mariannhill, early in the day after he allegedly stole a woman's bag. The victim later died from his injuries.

Unidentified assailants robbed and burned Chinese owned businesses in the Lethabong area of Rustenburg. The shop owners were tied and bound at the time of the attack. It is not clear if the businesses were targeted specifically because of Chinese ownership.
Employees of a tire factory protest for better wages. The workers had been on strike for three days at the time of the protest.
ANC volunteer in Wembezi hacked to death by unknown group
Municipality chief whips guard killed in mob attack; others injured.
A vigilante group attacked a man they suspected of being a thief. The man survived, but sustained injury.
