A organized debate between candidates of rival political parties descends into loud screaming and threats exchanged between members of the audience. The debate was held at Wits University. No reported violence.
One person hacked to death in Wembezi townships C Section
Tires and toilets burned by rioters in Esibaneni, protesting service delivery. Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowds
Leading ANC member in Wembezi C Section is shot and killed at his home
Two ANC supporters killed in uMshwathi

3000 of the SPRM protest the West Cape Premier as she appeared to the crowd to sign a memorandum they of demanded of her. Following the politicians departure the protesters toyi-toyied through the cities CBD.

A violent protest broke out in Brandvlei, Randfontein, west of Joburg when residents registered their frustrations over RDP houses that are still incomplete four years since the start of the project in 2010. Angry residents took to the streets and barricading areas of the R41 with rocks. They also burnt tyres and used stones to pelt vehicles. Police made several arrests. It is not clear if this protest was related to one in nearby Randfontein along the R28.
Service related protests; roads blocked and tires burned
Hundreds of Democratic Alliance supporters marched for jobs in Johannesburg.
Pupils protest outside Education Department offices in Cape Town over teacher strike

column7: APD: Association for Persons with Disabilities
column17: APD members hold a sit-in protest to raise awareness regarding issues relating to accessibility for people with disabilities within the business environment in Nelson Mandela Bay.
About 80 retired Transnet employees marched peacefully to the Union Buildings in Pretoria to call for an increase in their yearly pensions.
ANC supporters disrupt an EFF event at the University of KwaZulu-Natal. No reports of violence.
Unknown arsonists torched a small ANC office in Marikana

Unhappy about a spate of crime in their area, a vigilante mob attacked a group of hostel dwellers, believing they were the source of the unrest. In response, the hostel dwellers started burning tyres and sticks, while the residents were throwing rocks at them until late into the evening. Causalities/injuries unknown. The hostel building itself was destroyed by fire.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU, with the support of the alliance, led a march against the police station at Phokeng, complaining about safety of mining members
The eThekwini Land Invasion Unit injured two people while evicting residents from ""illegal"" settlements around Durban
A group of people travelled by bus from Limpopo to protest outside ARMs head office in Johannesburg
Striking port workers petrol-bombed, stoned and vandalised more than a dozen houses and properties of non-striking Ngqura container terminal workers

column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: SAWATU/ANC election truck attacked during door-to-door election campaigning at the mining area called Freedom Park

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: A protest by members of the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) at Polokwane Hospital in Limpopo expressed union members displeasure of a recently named hospital chief executive.
ANC supporters hold an anti-Zuma march through Durban, calling on supporters to vote in the upcoming general election.
Police arrested 70 people in Bloemhof after a number of houses, including those of eight police officers, were torched
In Rooigrond near Mahikeng, 12 people were arrested after a councillors house was set alight
At least 4,000 protestors were involved in day of violence near the northern city of Rustenburg; buildings/houses set on fire; politicians entourage attacked with stones
On 27 April 2014, three children were killed in suspected vigilante revenge raid in Mabidi.
Protesters gathered outside businessmans home to force him to repair a tree he previously damaged
Protesters gathered in Constantia with porta-potty toilets
A group of EFF supporters protested ANC governance

column6: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: A non-striking mine employee was allegedly attacked by people who were wearing Association of Mine Workers and Construction Union (Amcu) t-shirt at Mfidikwe near Rustenburg
A group of about 120 Numsa members protested outside the entrance gate to the Port of Ngqura
Minister of Water and Environmental Affairs Edna Molewa was held up by protesters near Nandoni Dam plant gates outside Thohoyandou
EFF protestors gathered at SABC offices in Johannesburg to protest banning of EFF advertisement
Finetown residents threw stones at motorists during a protest, with unclear motives
Protesters gathered in Bishopscourt with porta-potty toilets
Parents of students protesting over education
On 1 May 2014, a suspected vigilante attack on a member of a group terrorising the community in Fochville was reported.
Dozens of the station employees, including presenters, programmers and news staff, boycotted work on Friday morning and stagedprotests at the Khayelitsha Development Forum (KDF) offices.
Julius Melema led the EFF in a march to the SABC HQ in Auckland Park to hand in a memorandum of grievances, particularly what he sees as te muzzling of his party in the run-up to the elections

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Students (South Africa)
column17: A university student and Economic Freedom Fighters official was allegedly assaulted by a security guard at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) in Pretoria
A DA supporter was stoned to death after threats were made against the party
In two separate incidents in Gauteng, three buses were damaged and one driver hospitalised; ANC supporters allegedly threw stones at DA vehicles
In two separate incidents in Gauteng, three buses were damaged and one driver hospitalised; ANC supporters allegedly threw stones at DA vehicles
In Nyanga, three cars were damaged but nobody was injured; ANC allegedly threw stones at DA vehicles
A school set to be a polling station was firebombed in protest of elections; a boy was killed

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Vigilante Group (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa)
column9: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: SAMWU workers turned on a shop steward who pulled out a gun in a meeting
40 people were arrested in street unrest Monday in the East Rand
At least 5,000 people demonstrated for better government services in the Nsuze area in KwaZulu-Natal province
Service delivery protests
Unrest two days before elections
Unrest two days before elections
Special voting in KwaZulu-Natal was marred by at least three violent service delivery protests
Residents protest over poor service delivery by the local health clinic.
Rioters burned down election poll tents
Service delivery protests
Police allegedly attacked civilians in their homes
Forty-one people were arrested for public violence and arson after a community hall in Mandlazini, Richards Bay, was torched
ANC volunteer killed at polling station
A woman was allegedly assaulted by the police during a service delivery protest
Protests delayed opening of polls
Protests delayed opening of polls
Reports of violence around elections
Protests over elections
Protest over elections in 3 villages in Mqanduli
Residents of Phepheni village in Mt Ayliff, armed with pangas, axes and shields, blockaded a road demanding electricity from the Mzimvubu Municipality
Protests delayed opening of polls
Reports of violence around elections
Service protests and road blockages
Service delivery/election protests. 1 election tent burned down.
Service protests and road blockages
In KwaZulu-Natal, Kwadukuza, one person was shot in KwaMashu
Reports of violence around elections
Protests delayed opening of polls
A woman was killed when she was knocked down outside a voting station in Pietermaritzburg.
An incident was reported in Tzaneen, in Limpopo, where a voting station was ambushed by unknown assailants who had posed as voters
Vigilante mob kills 3 and injures 1; all accused robbers
Reports of violence around elections
Service delivery protests
Service delivery protests
Reports of violence around elections
Protests over elections
Protests delayed opening of polls
Pupils protesting lack of school teachers; prevented from reaching parliament by police
SA women demand captive Nigerian girls release
Vigilante mob beats up suspected mugger

ANGRY and frustrated Nelson Mandela Bay Grade R teachers yesterday stormed the cities Education Department offices, demanding clarity on why they were being placed under the Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP)
Rioting over election results in Alexandra
A mob linked to several KZN taxi associations set alight tyres in the middle of First Avenue in Greyville; a journalist was knocked down by the mob

column16: IOL; AFP; Cape Argus; Star (South Africa)
column17: Rioting over election results in Alexandra
EFF member killed by unidentified group
About 200 singing Egoli and Vergenoeg residents marched to the home of their ward councillor demanding housing, and giving her two weeks to deliver or resign
The mayor of an ANC-led municipality allegedly threw bricks at a taxi driver ferrying EFF supporters and attacked two other people
A husband and wife were attacked and killed in their home at Bapong village; both had gone back to work at area mine; violence took place within context of other strike-related killings
A miner was burned in his house amid platinum strike, near Marikana
Melikhaya Bunzi, 29, was allegedly beaten and stoned to death in a mob justice attack in Philippi yesterday
A group of about 70 parents locked the gates to Jadezweni Junior Secondary School in Lower Bolota, accusing administrators of misusing funds
Two mine workers hacked to death on the way to the mine for work
Riot police intercepted a group of shack dwellers from Siqalo informal settlement who travelled to the city to hear their fate in the Western Cape High Court
Vigilante attack on suspected thief in Khayelitsha in Cape Town
Protests that resulted in police firing rubber bullets to disperse a protest in Mmaditlokwe informal settlement, near Marikana
About 50 protesters rally against child rape accused getting bail
A mixture of students, university management and representatives from various campus societies gathered at Fort Hare University to show support for kidnapped girls in Nigeria
An explosive device was thrown at the home of the Cape defence attorney

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Cosatu picketing Heart FM over freedom of expression

Hundreds of striking miners gathered in Marikana near Lonmin mine outside Rustenburg in North West in an attempt to stop their colleagues from returning to work; stones were thrown at passing cars; 3 vehicles were burned at a mine

Hundreds of pupils from Upper Ngqungqu Junior Secondary School near Mqanduli wreaked havoc on Thursday; the rampage was sparked by the department of educations failure to build a proper school, despite many promises
Two men killed and three seriously injured in a shooting at a provincial building in Mmabatho
Protestors gathered near the Nigerian Embassy to demand the return of kidnapped Nigerian girls
A suspected cable thief was found hacked to death along Mkhangoma Road in Kwandengezi, KwaZulu-Natal
Hundreds of residents blockaded roads, stoned cars and clashed with police after municipal workers cut off their illegal electricity connections in Port Elizabeths Walmer township
A group of Khoisan occupy hall in Pinelands; protesting over land they claim is owed to them
Students, priests, pedestrians, and members of the ANC Womens League held a protest over the girls recently kidnapped in Nigeria
At the weekend residents and others from the nearby Sun City village, where two badly decomposed bodies were recently found in an open veld, staged protests when allegations of muthi killings emerged

Residents burned tyres along the R568 highway from KwaMhlanga to Libangeni, in Mpumalanga, as Ndebele King Makhosoke Mabena II and his bride Nozipho Mnguni exchanged vows at Engwenyameni Royal Palace nearby
Chaos broke out at East London Secondary School in Braelyn as parents and pupils protested against the return of principal

A group of disgruntled ANC members from the West Rand and Tshwane regions descended on the parties Luthuli House headquarters and staged a protest, calling for the disbandment of the PEC as punishment for the party losing support in the poll
About 200 people including children picketed outside the Flagstaff Magistrates Court, opposing bail for a sangoma who allegedly raped three young girls

Six Egoli residents including a four-year-old boy were injured in clashes with Buffalo City Metro law enforcement officers; residents said the violence started when officers arrived at the township and started demolishing shacks
A small group of Imizamo Yethu residents picketed in the central city over families having to move to accommodate a MyCiTi bus stop
Students locked themselves inside a Lusikisiki college when they heard a sheriff of the court was on the way to seize equipment they needed to study
A riot erupted in Hangberg yesterday after a man was arrested in what residents claim was an eviction; police broke up the riot and made arrests
Two ANC members were killed as they were walking home in Wembesi township, Escourt; another ANC member was injured in the leg

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Disgruntled SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) members marched to the Cape Town Civic Centre in protest against how line managers were treating them
Buffalo City College students allege they were injured when police fired rubber bullets to break up a protest; the incident involved a number of students at the John Knox campus in Mdantsane
Angry Missionvale residents from Ward 32 marched to the DA ward councillors office in Tromp Road and dumped a bucket of faeces on her doorstep
On 21 May 2014, attacks on foreign nationals; looting of foreign-owned shops in Gilead, Rebone; broken up by police with arrests. [size=no report]
On 21 May 2014, residents looted foreign-owned shops and chased foreigners from Gilead (Limpopo). 25 people were arrested. [size=at least 25]
Two men suspected of ATM fraud were severely beaten and stoned in a mob attack at the taxi rank in Mfuleni
Johannesburg Social Development employees took to the streets to protest against alleged misconduct by senior management
Eight people were arrested on public violence charges after more than 700 service delivery protesters in Magaliesburg blocked off the R509

column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: A member of NUM was stabbed and killed on his way to work at Union Mine in Limpopo, while others continue to strike
Hundreds of National Freedom Party (NFP) supporters blockaded a road with rubble and burning tyres in Wembesi township
More than 200 Retreat taxi drivers staged a protest march to the transport MECs offices in the city centre to hand over a memorandum of demands amid rising taxi-related violence
A group of pupils from a school in Barberton in Mpumalanga were brutally assaulted, allegedly by police, after cellphones hidden in the ceiling of their classroom were discovered during a raid

About 50 parents and pupils from Solomon Mahlangu made their way to the Education Departments Uitenhage district office to protest the failure by authorities to deliver the furniture to their newly renovated school
Mngeni Municipality offices were set alight by suspected municipal workers apparently demanding a wage increase
Residents protested against the abduction and rape of two local girls by blocking a road to the towns airport with rocks and burning tyres
On 23 May 2014, a vigilante attack on a suspected thief in Ekangala was caught on video.
Possible vigilante attack on a man suspected of being a thief
Durban activists joined the rest of the world yesterday in support of a global campaign against American company Monsanto
Thousands of protesters took to the streets in Uitenhage to deliver warning of intolerance to drug dealers
Supporters and accusers of a pastor accused of rape demonstrated outside the Khayelitsha Magistrates Court during his bail hearing
Pledging solidarity with unpaid workers, hundreds of villagers from nine affected villages blockaded the road into the area around Amabhele
Protest outside a local clinic, where residents were demanding better healthcare

A group of SA Municipal Workers Union members in Gauteng started gathering at the federations headquarters before a central executive committee meeting, demanding that their leaders answer to allegations of corruption or be fired
About 30 activists and supporters of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rights demonstrated and called for an alleged rapist to be given a harsh sentence
Students from the Soshanguve campus of Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) disrupted classes in protest over claims that the National Student Financial Aid Scheme was not being properly managed
A man was found hanging from a tree; death is suspected to be related to acts of violence and continued intimidation of non-striking mineworkers in the region

Two men were assaulted and stabbed multiple times while on their way to work in a nearby mine; attack is suspected to be related to acts of violence and continued intimidation of non-striking mineworkers in the region

column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Two houses belonging to NUM members were petrol bombed at Sefikile village next to Union Mine in North West Province by hooligans camouflaged as striking unionists

column7: YCL: Young Communist League; Students (South Africa)

Thousands of school children in northern KwaZulu-Natal have embarked on a three-day unsanctioned strike demanding the installation of electricity in the rural areas; police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Pomeroy, Msinga Top, Tugela Ferry, Mzweni, Qcwaka and Mzinyathi

Thousands of school children in northern KwaZulu-Natal have embarked on a three-day unsanctioned strike demanding the installation of electricity in the rural areas; police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Pomeroy, Msinga Top, Tugela Ferry, Mzweni, Qcwaka and Mzinyathi

Thousands of school children in northern KwaZulu-Natal have embarked on a three-day unsanctioned strike demanding the installation of electricity in the rural areas; police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Pomeroy, Msinga Top, Tugela Ferry, Mzweni, Qcwaka and Mzinyathi

Thousands of school children in northern KwaZulu-Natal have embarked on a three-day unsanctioned strike demanding the installation of electricity in the rural areas; police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Pomeroy, Msinga Top, Tugela Ferry, Mzweni, Qcwaka and Mzinyathi

Thousands of school children in northern KwaZulu-Natal have embarked on a three-day unsanctioned strike demanding the installation of electricity in the rural areas; police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Pomeroy, Msinga Top, Tugela Ferry, Mzweni, Qcwaka and Mzinyathi

Morning traffic on the North West Expressway was brought to a standstill as around 200 parents from St Johns Road Primary School protested against a teacher shortage, forcing vehicles to find alternate roads
Fed-up Malamulele High School pupils presented a memorandum at the police station over conditions at their school
Students again protested at Medunsas Ga-Rankuwa campus, continuing a two-week-long student protest; they blocked entrances, keeping staff from entering
About three hundred people blocked the R550 and the R554 roads in the south of Johannesburg, according to police
More than 200 pupils and parents protested outside Alexandria High School in the town over teacher shortages
More than 50 meter readers gathered outside the Pietermaritzburg Magistrates Court to show support for one of their own

Traffic on the N2 near Port Shepstone had to be diverted after disgruntled residents caused havoc during a violent service delivery protest; hundreds of people blocked the road with burning tyres and debris demanding ""fresh tap water"" after water cuts at the weekend; a man who is believed to have been one of the protesters was found dead nearby; his death is under investigation

column9: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Three NUMSA shopstewards leaders were killed and one was injured late at night in Isithebe in KwaZulu-Natal in a shooting
A riot occurred at a Mozambique-South Africa border post over new rules for travelers from Mozambique

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: Protesters from shackdweller movement Abahlali baseMjondolo (AbM) marched on the the Austrian honourary consul in Durban to protest the eviction of squatting ""comrades"" under way in Vienna, Austria
A car is shot at and its passengers injured in ongoing political violence withnin Kwamasha hostel.
Police dispersed rioters and cleared the R554 road in Eikenhof, south of Joburg; residents threw stones at passing cars in protest over shack demolitions
Nearly 100 members of the Black Business Forum and Nelson Mandela Bay SMMEs protested inside the Port Elizabeth High Court and on the front steps of the court building
Veeplaas residents marched to the Kwazakhele police station in Port Elizabeth to lobby for the release of two people arrested for burning down a shack belonging to an alleged robber
Students at the University of Fort Hares East London campus protested over tuition funding
Police dispersed rioters and cleared the R554 road in Eikenhof, south of Joburg; residents threw stones at passing cars in protest over shack demolitions
About 200 Da Gama Textiles workers took part in a peaceful protest outside the factory in Zwelitsha, joining 3000 textile workers in a countrywide strike for higher wages
Community members gathered in protest outside of a court in Sophiatown ahead of the appearance of a man accused of shooting a child
Marchers held up dirty underwear in front of the offices of the department of health in protest over service delivery
Tens of thousands of demonstrators march through Cape Town to protest against Israels bombardment of Gaza.
More than 100 people marched through the streets of Parkside, commemorating Womens Day by calling on women to break their silence on abuse
Rioters damaged a building, burned tyres and blocked roads during a service-delivery protest, days before a by-election
Parents began protesting in front of Kwelera Public School to demand a Grade 1 teacher for their children.

Southern Cape police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a 3 000-strong crowd in KwaNonqaba in Mossel Bay; this was after the protesters had torched a municipal building, set fire to a school, stoned cars on the N2 highway, and damaged police vehicles; this occurred days before a by-election

Heckling protesters disrupted an inquiry into the shooting dead of 34 striking miners by South African police, forcing the countries deputy president to briefly halt his testimony; police blocked them from entering the building

Police, the City of Cape Town Anti-Land Invasion Unit and law enforcement officials were pelted with rocks after shacks on an open field in the Marikana informal settlement in Philippi were demolished; authorities responded by firing rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse an angry crowd. A council official leading the demolition was assaulted and chased by a resident whose shack was torn down
Parents marched to the Mpumalanga Department of Education Offices in Nelspruit over the closing of a local school

Hundreds of Muvhavha Secondary School pupils held their principal hostage during a two-day strike in Tswinga village near Thohoyandou; the students threw rocks on the school roof and barricaded the gate, preventing their principal from leaving his office; police were called in to rescue the principal but no arrests were made

Hundreds of Muvhavha Secondary School pupils held their principal hostage during a two-day strike in Tswinga village near Thohoyandou; the students threw rocks on the school roof and barricaded the gate, preventing their principal from leaving his office; police were called in to rescue the principal but no arrests were made

Police used tear gas and a water cannon to disperse an angry crowd after a riot erupted on the steps of the Bellville Magistrates Court where the ""poo protesters"" began their trial; there were reports of injuries
Several protesters yelled at Deputy President Cyril Ramaphosa for a second day as he gave evidence at the Farlam Commission of Inquiry in Pretoria
Pupils protested outside Trichardtfontein Combined School because it remained closed; they blockaded parts of the N17 highway
Residents continued a violent protest against the demolition of 100 shacks erected at the Marikana informal settlement in Philippi; police responded to the violence

A heavy police contingent kept a watchful eye as about 200 singing students barricaded the road and the entrance to Galeshewe campus of the National Institute of Higher Education (NIHE); they were protesting over an announcement that the institution would be phased out; police used rubber bullets and arrested some students for public violence
A small group of people protested outside the District Six Museum to voice their unhappiness with Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT)
Protests continued in a Mossel Bay township over service delivery; police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse small crowds again. Protesters burned tires and threw stones.
Protesters, including a leader of the SesKhona Peoples Rights Movement, protested outside of the Bellville Magistrates Court over the poo protesters trial
A package left on a counter at Umbilo police station exploded; no injuries were reported and a motive was not given
A mob caught and severely injured a Pakistani man accused of shooting a local man who had allegedly robbed him

column7: MACUA: Mining Affected Communities United in Action
column17: Hundreds of people from mining communities marched on the mining lekgotla in Midrand, Johannesburg,in protest over not being included in matters affecting the industry

East London public order police yesterday fired rubber bullets, stun grenades and tear gas at hundreds of residents protesting in Berlin; six residents were reportedly injured and 23 arrested on a charge of public violence; the rioters burnt tyres and blocked roads

Residents in Diepsloot, north of Johannesburg, protested over drug abuse in the area; around 200 people had marched to the police station earlier and handed over an alleged drug dealer; eight scrap metal and gold and diamond exchange outlets were damaged by the community

On 13 August 2014, residents called for all foreign businesspeople to leave the area or face mob justice, following the shooting of a local man by a Pakistani businessman. The crowds destroyed and looted tuckshops belonging to foreigners. [size=no report]

Angry residents took to the streets of KwaNoqaba for a fourth day of protests, torching buildings and stoning cars, demanding an end to electricity disconnections and better basic services in their community; police were quick to respond to the unrest
ANC Youth League members marched to Cefups Academy in protest over alleged beatings of students by other students

Homes built at Marikana in Philippi have been torn down a third time by authorities amid clashes and arrests; in the ensuing stand-off residents threw stones and glass bottles, with officers responding with rubber bullets

Students in Kimberley continued their rampage and burning of tyres for a second day, protesting over an announcement that the institution would be phased out; police used rubber bullets and arrested some students for public violence

More than 3000 residents of Mbilwi village, near Sibasa in Limpopo, brought business activity in the town of Thohoyandou to a standstill when they marched against alleged police ineptitude in ritual murder cases

East London police clashed with residents in Duncan Village C-Section during a violent service delivery protest; the stand-off between police and residents in the informal settlement began shortly after midday and continued until police ran out of stun grenades, tear gas and rubber bullets

Western Cape police confronted protesters in KwaNonqaba in Mossel Bay for the fifth day, using stun grenades and tear gas to disperse an angry crowd that hurled stones at motorists during a protest over electricity
Stranded commuters protested outside the municipal bus depot in central Durban over a service interruption
Illegal settlers were evicted for a fourth day in Philippi; protesters clashed with authorities, throwing stones and using spades; police responded with stun grenades
Dark streets, homes and alleys in Helenvale in Port Elizabeths northern areas saw fed-up women from the neighbourhood picket in Stanford Road

A group of protesters, including members of Right2Know and the Social Justice Coalition, marched from Parliament to the Caledon Square police station in Buitenkant Street; about 100 people protested against ""police brutality"" in the Marikana informal settlement and in the mining town where the killing occurred
Violence was reported during a protest in Durbans KwaMashu hostels, police could not confirm the details

A group of women - mostly widows and relatives of the Marikana miners killed in 2012 - marched in a silent protest to the SABC on the eve of the second anniversary of the shooting of miners at Marikana
""Members of the prisons emergency security team shocked and beat about 20 inmates"" before singling out 6 for further abuse. Four were badly beaten, while 2 were severely injured.

Rioters threw stones and other missiles at police as they demolished shacks; the police responded with rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the crowds which were burning tires and other debris. No arrests but some injuries were reported.
A taxi boss was ambushed and killed by unknown gunmen.
An angry mob of taxi drivers killed an off-duty police officer and stole his service pistol near Engcobo.
ANC-alligned protesters riot over service delivery and demand the resignation of their Democratic Alliance ward councillor.

On 18 August 2014, the police fired stun grenades to disperse about 400 residents in Daveyton (Gauteng), who had erected barricades and fought with police to stop the opening of a new mall until their demands for the township to build more informal housing were met. [size= about 400]
A group of men killed a youth in what appeared to police to be an example of mob justice.
Police were attacked with stones by a mob when they tried to prevent an incidence of mob justice.

On 19 August 2014, foreign-owned shops were looted by groups of 6 to 12 people in Daveyton (Gauteng), in a continuation of a violent demonstration against the building of a mall on the prior day. No reports on injures or arrests. [size=6 to 12]

Residents of Mamelodi East barricaded streets with debris and burnt tires to protest against service disruptions (e.g. Electricity). There was a heavy police presence but no clashes or arrests reported.

Rioters clashed with riot police, throwing rocks, while police fired rubber bullets and used stun grenades to cover the renewed demolition of shacks. The rioters also threw rocks at a car and injured its driver.
The National Health and Allied Workers Union (NEHAWU) began a strike and gathered for a demonstration in front of the public works office in Mthatha.
2 men were allegedly killed by a group of 12 women in an incident of mob justice. They have since been arrested.
Residents of Mamelodi East continued their protest against service disruptions (e.g. Electricity) through the night from Tuesday. There was a heavy police presence but no clashes or arrests reported.
People angry about the repeated demolition of shacks in Khayelitsha threw stones and at least one petrol bomb at a train, damaging it. They also damaged other property, including police vehicles.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: Members of the ANCWL protested outside the Khayelitsha Magistrates Court against abuse of women related to an ongoing trial.
Thousands of people too to the streets of Addo to march against insecurity in the area.
Protesters took to the streets to demand electricity. The police monitored the crowd and prevented them from blocking the roads.
The EFF staged a protest in Parliament to demand President Zuma respond to questions over alleged use of public money in upgrading his home. Riot police were called in to remove the EFF protesters.
The Tubatse Residents Association took to the streets in protest to call attention to their anger at the local mayor for a variety of alleged offenses.
A small march occurred in support of women's rights in Claremont.
Residents of Mooi Mpofana Local Muncipality began a protest to demand that the local mayor be removed.

Informal traders rioted in Tshwane, creating barricades that blocked traffic and throwing burning debris at cars after police attempted to seize stock from the traders. Some were arrested and charged with public violence.

Police clashed with shackdwellers in Philippi East. Rioters threw stones at police, while police responded with rubber bullets, stun grenades and tear gas. At least one rioter was shot with live ammunition.
Police fire tear gas at people burning tyres and threwing stones to show their dissatisfaction with Mayor Mondli Gungubeles speech.
Gauteng Grade R teachers took to the streets in Joburg CBD to protest against their exclusion from the school system.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU and allies picketed the North Gauteng High Court to protest against the postponement of a case against the directors of Aurora.

Outraged municipal workers were not paid on time on Monday, resulting in the workforce chasing a manager through the streets of Grahamstown. The acting municipal manager fled into oncoming traffic as workers attempted to force open his car door

EFF MPs protested in Parliament to demand President Jacob Zuma answer questions related to alleged spending of public funds for personal use. Police were called but as it was a peaceful protest they did not intervene.

10 people were injured after violence erupted during an eviction of residents from a building in the Hillbrow area. Gunshots were fired from the building and local police were deloyed to restore peace and order. Police used rubber bullets against the residents and allegedly beat them.

Residents of Mooi Mpofana Local Muncipality engaged in a protest action which blocked traffic on the busy N3 highway. A rapid response team was deployed to stop the blockage. 10 protesters were arrested.
Unidentified gunmen shot three people as they were leaving Bishop Lavis Magistrates Court, killing 1 and wounding 2. It was believed to be gang-related violence.

Students at Azara Secondary School rioted over demands for better facilities and services, among other things. They broke many windows, damaged a telephone line, and threatened to light the principal on fire. 6 students were suspended.

column9: MATA: Marapyane Taxi Association; Simunye Taxi Association; Makata Taxi Association
column17: Mata, Makata and Simunye Taxi Associations blockade the taxi routes in the early hours of Monday, bringing all taxi operations to a standstill. This is to protest Centrap Top X1 Taxi Association poaching their customers. During the demonstration there were reports of violence and assault.
People evicted from their home in Hillbrow on Monday have declared that they will stay camped outside the building until allowed back in.
A human resources employee was severely injured after being hit with stones by laid off casual postal workers angry about losing their jobs.
Protesters vandalise the district education building in Mdantsane. The protest was over teacher shortages.

column7: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-); Women (South Africa)
column17: Scenery Park residents and police marched together through the streets to protest against violence against women in their community.
Police and private security in riot gear dispersed a student protest. The students were unhappy about a proposed increase to the registration fees.
Residents of Gasekgopo protested over continued lack of water in their communities due to broken borehole machines.
Members of the ANC gathered outside Parliament and allegedly began singing ""shoot Malema"" before demanding to be allowed into the chambers. The police prevented them from entering.

A group of protesters barricaded the N4 near Witbank. They torched a bus and thre cars are passing vehicles. He police dispersed the group without injury or arrest. No reason was given for the protest.
Grahamstown ""ground to a halt on Wednesday as about 500 residents marched to the city hall, chanting and demanding that the entire council step down""
About 1500 residents of Mooi Mpofana Local Muncipality blocked the N3 and threw rocks at passing cars. Police used rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the crowd.
Residents of Valhalla protested to demand a return of electricity to the neighborhood after being without it for 8 months.
About 100 protesters barricaded a road with burning tyres, fencing and rocks to demand an official of their village step down over allegations he is blocking development.

Residents of Ekurhuleni protested to demand electricity and water services for their homes as well as the building of public buildings. They barricaded roads with burnt tires and rocks. 12 people were arrested for public violence.
Picketeers in Durban demonstrated in front of Woolworths to demand a boycott of Israeli goods until a permanent peace settlement with Palestinians is reached.

Residents of Mbilwi set one house on fire and damaged three others after a woman named people she accused of being involved in ritual murders. 8 people have been placed under police custody to protect them from angry Mbilwi residents.
Saldanha residents marched in protest over the lack of police investigation following the murder of a man during the weekend.

column9: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: ""Scores of people were injured when ANC members descended on a hall in Wembesi township, outside Estcourt, at the weekend."" SANCO was hosting a meeting in the hall. Those injured included SANCOs regional leader Wanqa Makua who was taken to the hospital.
2 metro policemen allegedly shoved and punched a couple after the husband attempted to record their license plate and get a video of the officers faces after being fined.
Staff of the Eastcape Midlands College have staged a sit-in on Uitenhage campus, vowing not to leave until issues of alleged misadministration, fraud and corruption are dealt with.

A taxi driver was shot dead and at least seven buses of the Golden Arrow Bus Services company were set on fire during a violent protest, while four others were badly damaged. 11 bus drivers were also assaulted. It is believed the perpetrators were taxi drivers. 8 people have been arrested in connection. This happened during protests in Nyanga and Philippi East.

A taxi driver was shot dead and at least seven buses of the Golden Arrow Bus Services company were set on fire during a violent protest, while four others were badly damaged. 11 bus drivers were also assaulted. It is believed the perpetrators were taxi drivers. 8 people have been arrested in connection. This happened during protests in Nyanga and Philippi East.

A delivery truck was attacked allegedly by taxi drivers, and the driver chased off. The police dispersed the crowd, but they later returned after the truck had been taken to the police station to loot it and set it on fire.
Protesters gathered outside the Durban Magistrates Court to demand ""witchcrafters and murderers to be burnt alive"" during the trial of several suspected murderers.
Demonstrators riot over service delivery and set fire to an ambulance.

Residents of Ennerdale protested against unfulfilled election promises. At least one threw a rock and broke a car windshield. Police fired rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the crowd. 2 police vehicles were allegedly hit with stones and one police officer hurt. 2 women were also arrested.
Residents of Ruyterwacht protested against plans to raise rent despite lack of maintenance of their properties.

Parents of students at Ntji Mothapo Primary School barricaded the school entrance with stones and burning tires to protest against alleged mismanagement of school funds, the principal, and the teachers with the SADTU, who they say abuse students.
Staff of the Eastcape Midlands College have continued a sit-in on Uitenhage campus, vowing not to leave until issues of alleged misadministration, fraud and corruption are dealt with.
Students protesting over planned increases to registration fees set trash cans and tires on fire and threw stones and bottles. Police deployed a water cannon to disperse the protesters.
Taxi drivers rioted in Nyanga, incurring heavy fines from the police.
Residents of Friendship Town near Tembisa created blockades with burning tires and rocks to demand ownership of their flats rather than renting.
A number of laid off casual post office workers burned rubbish and blockaded roads outside the Randburg post office to protest losing their jobs.
Some laid off casual post office workers angry about losing their jobs set a post office van at the Rosebank post office.
200 people, along with 26 dismissed ANC councillors, try to force their way into the council building.
Residents protest over lack of service delivery.
Residents blockade road to demand the installation of speedbumps.
Truck drivers for the Elgin Free Range Chickens company went on strike and began blocking the gates to the abattoir and the production plant.

column9: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: ANC members attacked and assaulted people at a meeting of its ally, the SA National Civic Organisation
Residents of Mzinti demonstrated over lack of service delivery in the area (water/electricity).
An off-duty police officer is assaulted and shot by taxi drivers in his home.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column9: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Fighting between SAMWU members and guards of SAMWUs HQ broke out, with at least one live round being fired by the guards and tear gas used on SAMWU members. The SAMWU members allegedly threw bricks, prompting retaliation with pepper spray by the guards. Three union members were harmed, and one deputy secretary of the union.

Students went on strike. They damaged some of the school property and prevented officials from entering the campus. They had been complaining about lack of funds in the National Student Financial Aid Scheme.
Scores of people marched to the Western Cape legislature to demand the recommendations of the Khayelitsha Commission of Inquiry be implemented.
""Molteno residents and farmers yesterday blocked the towns main road at both ends in protest as Bhisho prepared to place the Inkwanca Municipality under administration.""
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.

About 15 anti-e-toll protesters who were presenting banners on Ontdekkers bridge to cars passing by on the N1 highway were stopped by police, who proceeded to remove their banners and tell them to leave.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.

column7: SWEAT: Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Taskforce
column17: 50 members of the Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Taskforce (SWEAT) staged a protest to call for decriminalization of sex workers following five sex workers being killed in the past two months in Cape Town.
South African Muslims of the Claremont Main Road Mosque protested silently against the ""radical jihadist group the Islamic State (IS).""
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.
Students riot over registration fees for three days in four different campuses: Pinetown, Pietermaritzburg, Wetville and Howard College in Berea.

""Three vehicles were damaged when Inkwanca ANC branches clashed in Sterkstroom on Sunday."" Inkwanca has four branches, two in Molteno and two in Sterkstroom, which are embroiled in a contest to have their municipality played under Section 139 administration.
An ANC official was shot and taken to hospital in an alleged assassination attempt.
An IFP official was stabbed four times outside of his house in an alleged assassination attempt.

column16: IOL; Diplomat News Network (Somalia); Pretoria News
column17: On 8 September 2014, demonstrations occurred in Mamelodi between Monday and Thursday, including looting of foreign owned shops by youths and roadblocked with burning tyres, as residents expressed anger over lack of service delivery. They also demanded the removal of illegal shacks present on land due for development. It was reported that a Somali trader was also killed when hit by stones during the riots. 7 people were arrested in connection. [size=at least 7]

Hundreds of Seskhona Peoples Rights Movement (SPRM) members protested outside the Western Cape High Court to demand the right to protest as an interdict against the SPRM to stop them from organizing ""illegal"" protests.
Violent disruptions by students were reported at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University.
Violent protests occurred at the Vaal University of Technology, which disrupted classes and led to damage to property, prompting the university to suspend classes.
A man suspected of being a serial killer is beaten and his house burnt down by local residents.

On 9 September 2014, demonstrations occurred in Mamelodi between Monday and Thursday, including looting of foreign owned shops by youths and roadblocked with burning tyres, as residents expressed anger over lack of service delivery. [size=no report]
Riots break out over 16 allegedly corrupt appointments to the local Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP). The police use teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the rioters.
Seskhona Peoples Rights Movement supporters came in their numbers to protest outside the Western Cape High Court about an interdict the City of Cape Town seeks to stop them protesting.

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Students (South Africa)
column17: The Vaal University of Technology allegedly forcefully evicted students, with at least one seriously injured and others receiving minor injuries. An EFF student leader was also allegedly arrested for trying to intervene on the students behalf after a security guard threatened to shoot students. Vaal University denies that violent evictions took place.

""Classes were suspended on Tuesday and Wednesday because of protests by students about a lack of funds in the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS)."" On Tuesday a bus was burnt by protesting students.

2 people accused of witchcraft were killed after being pelted with stones by a mob of villagers and their bodies then burned, and 2 homes burnt down. 16 people have been arrested in connection, with another 7 being sought.
""Two days of violent student protests at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, which resulted in at least three injuries and damage to property, have ended, according to the universities management.""

On 10 September 2014, demonstrations occurred in Mamelodi between Monday and Thursday, including looting of foreign owned shops by youths and roadblocked with burning tyres, as residents expressed anger over lack of service delivery. [size=no report]
""Classes were suspended on Tuesday and Wednesday because of protests by students about a lack of funds in the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS).""
Property destruction: A city ward councillors house is burnt down in a suspected arson attack. The attack is tied to service delivery protests.
Employees march demanding to be moved from their current unsafe work place of Caxton House.

Violence broke out after an armed group of security guards were brought in to disperse students at Vaal residences after students were given 24 hours to vacate the residences indefinitely. Pepper spray, ""knobkerries"" and pellet guns were used to disperse ""rioting students.""
""Two days of violent student protests at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, which resulted in at least three injuries and damage to property, have ended, according to the universities management.""

300 supporters of dismissed mayor Mthandazo Qamngwana attack Molteno civic and ANC members, townspeople and farmers in Sterkstroom. Police intervene on behalf of the ANC members and clash with the rioters.
300 supporters of dismissed mayor Mthandazo Qamngwana attack Molteno civic and ANC members, townspeople and farmers in Sterkstroom.
About 200 Pakistani nationals demonstrated outside the Mthatha Forensic Pathology Unit after a Pakistani businessman was killed, to demand better protection from the government/police.

On 11 September 2014, demonstrations occurred in Mamelodi between Monday and Thursday, including looting of foreign owned shops by youths and roadblocked with burning tyres, as residents expressed anger over lack of service delivery. [size=no report]
Students at TUT protested again over lack of funds in the National Student Financial Aid Scheme and over perceptions that some of the lecturers are racist.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column16: BBC News; South African Press Association
column17: A large numer of people demonstrated outside the Pretoria High Court alongside Steenkamps family, including members of the ANC Womens League, who sang and danced in support of Steenkamps family.

column7: Students (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Protesters again demonstrate against 16 allegedly corrupt appointments to the local Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP). The EFF supports the protesters.
Post office workers burned down a postal depot in Soweto as relations broke down between employees and employers related to postal strikes.
More than one hundred residents, along with various religious groups, marched through the streets of Heideveld to protest against the increase in gang turf wars and the drug trade in the area.
Activist group Equal Education (EE) march to the office of Gauteng Education MEC Panyaza Lesufi, in Johannesburg, to demand better sanitation facilities in schools.
Hundreds of bikers from Bikers Against Tolls (BAT) shut down lower Adderley Street during a protest against proposed implementation of e-tolls in Western Cape.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANCYL protests outside an event chaired by Guateng MEC to thank the role of Jewish South Africans in the anti-Apartheid struggle.
Taxi drivers staged a strike in protest against their bosses. A fight broke out after owners decided to drive the taxis themselves, leading to at least one taxi driver being shot in the leg.

Police fired rubber bullets and used teragas to disperse more than 1,000 people protesting over service delivery at the Grabouw municipal offices. Police claim protesters threw stones as they marched in Ou Kaapse Weg. Earlier in the day they had forced the closure of the N2 highway by throwing stones at cars. They then poured oil on the highway and used large rocks and tires to blockade the town. Looting was reported and shots were heard late on Monday night.
""The Democratic Alliance marched to the Oudtshoorn Municipality on Monday morning in protest against alleged mismanagement of the area.""
Villagers assaulted a man who they believed had tried to rape two women. Police intervened but the man later died in hospital. 1 person was arrested in connection.
Angry protesters burn tyres and block the road to demonstrate against the lack of water provision.

Residents of several sections of Soshanguve closed down the municipal offices in Akasia for more than an hour during a protest in the township. After an argument with police, their grievances were presented to a senior municipal official.
The universities Pretoria campus is shut down after students riot.

Residents of the Fynbos Squatter Camp blocked the Mdantsane Access Road with burning tires, waste and tree branches as part of a service delivery protest. Security forces were dispatched, but no arrests were made or injuries reported.

column7: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards
column17: Prison wardens began a sit-in at Kutama Sinthumule Correctional Centre to demand attention for their grievances.
A section of the N2 highway was closed due to protesters throwing rocks at cars as part of a service delivery protest. Schools were also forced to close due to the violent protests.

Parents of the schools boycotting annual national assessments marched to a neighbouring school in Gelvandale and demonstrated outside, to force the school which was carrying out the ANA to close in reprisal.

There was a protest in Vrygrond on Cape Flats related to a shortage of taxi-operating licenses, which became violent, including the use of stun grenades and rubber bullets on the police side and rocks being thrown by protesters.

Protesters in Grabouw set a fire staton alight and closed parts of the N2 with rocks and rubning wood for three hours. Protesters also marched on the municipalities offices in Grabouw. Police used stun grenades, water cannons and rubber bullets. Protesters protected themselves with iron shields and threw rocks.

""Eleven people were arrested yesterday during another violent protest in Fynbos squatter camp."" Around 100 residents protested over a lack of houses and electricity. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets while protesters blocked roads and threw stones at vehicles.

""At least 13 schools have now been shut down in Port Elizabeths troubled northern areas due to an ongoing teacher shortage protest."" These have been carried out by parents, and continued/expanded from Sept.16.

column16: Mercury (South Africa); South African Press Association
column17: Students engaged in renewed violent protests at the TUT, beginning with attempts to block the gates of the campuses, forcing them to close. Police were called in and security was increased. Soshanguve saw clashes between students and security personnel.

More than 1000 businessmen, traders and workers marched to demand justice and police protection after repeated attacks against foreign shop owners. Most of the marchers were Pakistani, but they were joined by numerous other nationalities.
A traditional headman is shot and killed while on duty and managing a dispute over stolen cattle.
18 cars are set alight amid ongoing riots at TUT.

Around 10 Muslim men protested during the opening of South Africas first gender-equal, gay-friendly, non-sectarian mosque. They tried to block the doors, but eventually let people in without incident. A crowd heckled the proprietor of the open mosque and threaten to kill him.

Around 50 residents of the Philippi East informal settlement demonstrated outside the Athlone Magistrate Court to support the application of bail for 12 fellow residents who have been detained for about a month.
Rioters burn down the office of a Philippi councellor for blocking a project in their settlement.
A traditional headman is killed in his home.
500 SACP members protest against rising facism and the Economic Freedom Fighters.
Scores of activists march to demand clean energy. The march is organised by activist communities Avaaz and 350.org
Residents of the Ezenketheni informal settlement protest against lack of service delivery, especially the lack of electricity. Rioters blockade the road and are dispersed by the police.
Parents angry at the appointment of a permanent school principle march to the district education offices to protest and had over a memorandum of understanding.
Rioters burn tires and barricade local roads.
On 22 September 2014, two Pakistani shop owners in Khuma were stabbed and their store was looted after one of the owners allegedly stabbed a local man who was stealing from his store.
Hundereds of pensioners protest outside parliament over unpaid pensions.

Hundereds of local township residents assemble in Kirkwood on Tuesday to protest against, among other issues, lack of tarred roads, unreliable water provision and allegations of fraud at Sundays River Valley municipality. Local ANC offices are set alight.
Rioters burn tires and barricade local roads.
Employees at Bay TV are refusing to work because they have not been paid since June.
Hundereds of pensioners protest outside parliament over unpaid pensions.
Two teachers are seriously injured by rioting students.
Rioters assemble outside the district offices and burn tires due to a backlog in housing allocation and problems in service delivery.

About 250 informal settlement residents riot over jobs and services they were promised back in 2010. The rioters barricade the N2 motorway. The local police respond by dispersing the protest with rubber bullets.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: The opening ceremony of a new multipurpose development in central Johannesburg is invaded by a group of about 50 protesters wearing ANC Youth League T-shirts.
Several vehicles are burnt and people hospitalised in a clash between a local taxi association and a newly formed metered taxi group.
Community members beat a suspected robber to death.
Jossey Buthane, the EFFs Limpopo co-ordinator and chief whip in the provincial legislature, beats up a fellow party member.
Community members stone a suspected rapist to death.
Members of the Right2Know (R2K) Campaign protest in Pretoria and demand that the Seriti Commission of Inquiry into the 1999 arms deal be dissolved.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: A handful of ANC Youth League supporters protested outside Woolworths headquarters in Cape Town demanding that the retail giant cut trade ties with Israel.
Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) members stage an all-night vigil in Polokwane ahead of their commander-in-chiefs court case on charges of corruption.

column9: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement; Women (South Africa)
column17: A branch chairperson of the Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement, is gunned down in her shack by an unknown assailant. Another person is injured in the attack and is in critical condition. The movement names a local ANC ward councillor as a suspect in ordering the killing
A group of Hangberg protesters attack the upmarket Panorama Hill complex which has been built on what some residents said is land that could beused for housing for the poor.
A resident is beaten and arrested for contravening an order against further settlement in the area.
Illegal settlers protest outside Mthatha court where one of their leaders stands trial of obstruction.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Angry local residents protest against not being hired as contractors to build the new headquarters of the Office of Statistics.
Striking farm workers barricade the R62 near Joubertina and destroy property. Police try to disperse the crowd but are targeted with petrol bombs.
Local residents attack council speaker Xolile Nkompela in a demonstration against the dismissal of local councillor Mkhuseli Mathe.
About 19 fire and safety inspectors employed by the city staged a sit-in protest at the municipal managers offices demanding their September salaries.
Cyclists protest outside the court case of a driver who hit a cyclist.
A group of Hangberg protesters attack the upmarket Panorama Hill complex which has been built on what some residents said is land that could beused for housing for the poor.
Local residents assault the inhabitants of a homestead believed to be hiding a pastor suspected of ritual murder.
DA members gather at the national transport departments offices in Pretoria to protest against e-tolls.
A fire station manager goes on a one-man demonstration to protests against witchcraft and drunkeness at his station.

About 100 employees of Vimba Security protested outside the companies offices in Braamfontein over wages and severance packages. The dismissal of the guards is allegedly linked to a recent incident in which a nurse was raped.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Members of the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) marched to Parliament yesterday with a long list of demands to overhaul the health sector.The demands of the protesters were varied, and many: the immediate release of the white paper on the National Health Insurance; for vacancies to be filled; tighter regulation of medical aid schemes and private hospitals; a curb on rising medical aid premiums; a restructuring of the Government Employees Medical Scheme (GEMS) board; an end to the ""unholy alliance of the big private hospitals""of the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) marched to Parliament yesterday with a long list of demands to overhaul the health sector.The demands of the protesters were varied, and many: the immediate release of the white paper on the National Health Insurance; for vacancies to be filled; tighter regulation of medical aid schemes and private hospitals; a curb on rising medical aid premiums; a restructuring of the Government Employees Medical Scheme (GEMS) board; an end to the ""unholy alliance of the big private hospitals""

A battle between ANC and EFF members at Kgotsong, Bothaville, Free State has left four houses damaged, two torched and 12 people in custody. Three of the damaged houses belonged to ANC councillors and one to an EFF leader, while one of those set alight was the home of an EFF member and the other belonged to an ANC councillor
Property destruction: The Open Mosque, which allows entrance to non-Muslims and homosexuals, was burnt down by unknown perpetrators.

A metro policeman shoots a taxi rank manager in full view of the passengers. The policeman reportedly stopped the taxi, grabbed the driver and shot him. Police had been chasing a taxi suspected of running a red light. The taxi driver allegedly had a knife.
Activists march against the poaching and killing of African wildlife.
Activists march against the poaching and killing of African wildlife.
Activists march against the poaching and killing of African wildlife.
Activists march against the poaching and killing of African wildlife.
Activists march against the poaching and killing of African wildlife.
Students march to draw attention to social ills affecting South Africa.
Residents riot and cause R100m worth of damage after a local is killed by flying debris caused by mining.

Residents of Buqaqawuli informal settlement in New Brighton, Port Elizabeth, close the Ward 16 councillors office, and demand to see the building layout plan of the development in the ward. The dispute stems from the fact that building has started in a neighbouring settlement but not in in Buqaqawuli.
Protesters from Kathrada Park riot over a lack of RDP housing which they said they had been promised 12 years ago. They clash with security at Newclare station. One person is killed in the crossfire.
Ennerdale community members block roads and burn tyres in protest over housing.

Three government officials were held by protesting residents of Kwa-Nonkululeko in Ndakana village near Stutterheim. Police had to use force to disperse an angry crowd who kept several government employees hostage.

Over 200 residents of Khayelitsha informal settlement blocked the main road to Berlin yesterday morning with burning tyres and cardboard in a protest to get electricity connected to their shacks. Police clash with the rioters uwith rubber bullets.
Hundreds of prisoners at the West Bank Correctional Service protest about not getting bread with their meals.
Two suspected robbers are burnt to death by a mob.

More than 400 people from Chatsworth, on Groene Rivier Farm, protested outside Swartland municipalities offices, where police formed a human barricade in response to the marchers threatening to enter the building. No injuries were reported.

Clashes erupt between metro police officers and rioting informal traders in what traders claim to have been another episode in a series of violent and forced removals from their stalls. Two police vehicles are damaged and traders block the road with burning debris.
Private security guards at Lindela Repatriation Center fire rubber bullets and assault 25 Nigerian migrants for refusing to eat. 14 inmates were injured.
Local residents riot after three men die trying to illegally tap into the electricity grid.
Twenty activists protest at a mining conference over not being given a fair share of a mine in their local area.
A minibus taxi was set alight in Pretoria West during a battle between two taxi associations in the area.
A Zimbabwean suspected of murder is killed by a group of local residents after two bodies are found in his rental accommodation.
Local residents clash with police after a suspected criminal accused of terrorising the neighbourhood is released from police custody.
A suspected criminal accused of terrorising the neighbourhood is burnt to death by residents after being released from police custody.
Protesters dance outside the court case of nine people who were arrested for dumping the waste at the entrance of the terminal on June 25 last year.
Villagers protest and demand that their recently dismissed ward councillor,Mkhuseli Mathe, be reinstated.

Hundreds of Ezinketheni informal settlement residents are protest outside the Pietermaritzburg Magistrates Court for the release of 15 suspects that were arrested in connection with the murders of two suspected robbers.

column16: Sowetan (South Africa); Institute for Security Studies
column17: On 9 October 2014, Nigerian nationals were attacked by local residents in Mafikeng (Ngaka Modiri Molema), accusing them of selling drugs and destroying the local community. [size=no report]

Clashes erupt between metro police officers and rioting informal traders in what traders claim to have been another episode in a series of violent and forced removals from their stalls. Two police vehicles are damaged and traders block the road with burning debris.
Local residents apprehend a suspected drug dealer of Nigerian origin and march him to the local police station where they protest against police inefficiency.

Community leaders from Masetlahlaneng, Mzombane, Masodi, GaModiba, Masesetjane, Kgobodi, Tshamahansi and GaMagongoa protest against Ivanhoe mining company. The protests stem from Ivanhoe mining breaking environmental regulation.

column7: TBF: Tshwane Barekisi Forum; SACP: South African Communist Party
column17: Members of the South African Communist Party (SACP) and Tshwane Barekisi Forum marched to the Union Buildings to hand over a memorandum against alleged corruption in the City of Tshwane and constant harassment of informal traders by metro police officers.
Cape Towns Kurdish community staged a protest in support of Kurds fighting against Islamic State (IS) militants in the besieged Syrian town of Kobane.

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards
column17: Five warders in St Albans prison are stabbed during a prison riot that occurred after non-gang members were put in the same cells as gang members.
SDCEA march to Egan Refinery to demand harsher punishments for chemical polluters in the local community.
Over 1 000 Reservoir Hill residents take to the streets to vent their anger at the high levels of crime.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: The ANC Youth League in Gauteng, together with Daveyton community members, march to the police station to protest against the increase of crime in the area.
Taxi drivers blockade the road to protest against the Go Durban! transport system.

Residents burn tyres and block roads with uprooted trees and other barricades in a service delivery protest against water bills and lack of electricity and water supply. Police attempt to disperse the group with rubber bullets.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Protesters demonstrate of the lack of servvice delivery and block the road with rocks.
EFF MPL Patrick Sindane leads Krugersdorp residents to the Mogale City municipallity to protest about water and electricity
Vehicles belonging to the SA Post Office (Sapo) are set alight outside the Sapo building in Chiawelo by suspected SAPO workers. SAPO is currently dealing with an ongoing strike by workers.
Local township residents burn furniture and throw faeces to protest crime in their neighbourhoods. The police are present but do not use any force.
Striking paramedics march to the EMS office in Midrand to hand in a memorandum of demands, including salary raises.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Parents protest over the appointment of a new school principle. Threats are shouted but no reports of violence or destruction of property.
The EFF and workers fired from an ABI owner-driver scheme protest at the companies offices in Sandton, Johannesburg
Parents take to the streets of Klarinet to demand that their children be bused to school. The bus service stopped due to unpaid salaries.
Residents protest over housing allocation.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
A group led by the Bo-Kaap neighbourhood watch, picket outside an alleged drug house.
Kimberly residents protest against the ""inhumane slaughter and oppression of the white ethnic minority of South Africa"".
Casual postal employees picket outside the Tshwane Mail centre and burn tyres in protest against the slow pace of negotiations to turn casual labourers into permanent employees.

column7: TAC: Treatment Action Campaign; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Residents and Treatment Action Campaign activists protest over poor service delivery by the local health clinic.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Residents of Lingelethu protest outside the magistrates court during the trial of a Lingelethu resident for public violence.

Hangberg residents demonstrate at the Wynberg Magistrates Court on Thursday in support of Santonio Jonkers, a man arrested for contravening a court order interdicting settlement in an informal settlement in Hangberg .
Sonke Gender Justice protest outside the trial of a man accused of murdering a homosexual man. Protesters claim that police had been slow with their investigations.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: Non-striking miners are attacked by striking NUMSA workers at Glencore mine.
Two suspected criminals are beaten to death by a vigilante mob.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Protesters burn their unpaid e-toll bills on top of an empty coffin while singing the national anthem outside Sanrals offices in Pretoria.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU lead a drive-slow campaign in protest of the e-toll system.
Around 200 people march in Cape Town as part of a Right2Know campaign to lower mobile call rates and transform the media.
A group of backyard dwellers from Ward 108 in Mfuleni destroy several shacks belonging to people who have been relocated to the land by the City Council

Arsonists set fire to memorabilia including portraits, files and a bronze bust highlighting the life and times of Tambo. The incident reprotedly stems from a dispute between two villages over the building of houses.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Parents lock teachers out a primary school and demand that the principal be removed.

column9: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: AN ANC branch chairman and regional Sanco organiser was shot and killed while returning home from a community meeting in Philipp. Provincial ANC secretary Songezo Mjongile said Kankus death was politically motivated.
Service delivery protest. No reports of violence.
Demonstrators protest over service delivery and block the road with burning tyres.
Demonstrators protest over service delivery and block the road with burning tyres.
Service delivery protest. No reports of violence.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.
Demonstrators barricade road with burning tyres. The protesters call for local ANC councillor Mduduzi ""Nqola"" Ngcobo to step down.
A group of youths from one of Mthathas suburbs marches to the office of the public protector and demand an investigation into allegations of RDP housing corruption.
2000 KwaZulu-Natal land claimants march to the Rural Development Departments office in Pietermaritzburg demanding that their claims lodged by attorneys be accepted.
Residents of New Village informal settlement use stones to block the road in a nine day service delivery protest over the lack of low-cost housing.

Residents try to block bulldozers sent to destroy their shacks by the municipal authorities. Police disperse crowd with teargas and rubber bullets. No reports of violence by demonstrators or serious injuries.
Atteridge post office is set alight by an unknown group. The arson attack occurs amid negotiations between the postal service and striking workers.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: NUMSA marches over possible retrenchments at a company where it organises. NUMSA leaders call for Zuma to resign.

A riot broke out when taxi drivers held a meeting with senior taxi association officials to voice their unhappiness with certain issues relating to the running of taxis. Vehicles are destroyed and two people are injured.
Unidentified group petrol bomb municipal vehicles. The action is believed to be related to issues regarding service delivery.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: Members of South Africas student congress place a pigs head in the Kosher aisle of Woolworths in protest of the chains continuing business relationship with Israeli suppliers.
Anti-Israeli demonstrators protest inside Woolworths.

Protesters from the Siqalo informal settlement shut down a section of Vanguard Drive for nearly five hours by dumping hundreds of waste containers from portable toilets in the road. The protesters are a small group of workers who live in Siqalo who were sub-contracted to an energy efficiency goods and installation company. The protest is due to tensions between the workforce and employer over issues of health and safety.
Anti-Israeli demonstrators protest inside Woolworths. 57 protesters are arrested by police and later released.
A mob kill a man accused of murdering a resident.
Students protest after finding out that they will have to repeat grades next year.
Sir Lowrys Pass Village residents block the road with burning debris in protest over the failure in electricity provision.
Residents, calling for councillor Ngcobo to be ousted, burn down three municipality vehicles and the councillors office.
Reiger Park residents protest outside the trial of a man accused of killing a local 4-year-old in a carjacking.
West End clinic staff members picketeoutside the clinic yesterday, demanding the Eastern Cape Health Department beef up security after a security guard is shot.
MK veterans illegally occupy vacant housing in protest of their poor treatment since the end of apartheid.
MK veterans illegally occupy vacant housing in protest of their poor treatment since the end of apartheid.
200 ANC supporters march to the municipal offices to demand the immediate resignation of all their municipal councillors.
MK veterans illegally occupy vacant housing in protest of their poor treatment since the end of apartheid.
The South African Destitute Forum and ex-mine workers from Queenstown march to the labour department offices to demand the payment of Unemployment Insurance Funds.
MK veterans illegally occupy vacant housing in protest of their poor treatment since the end of apartheid.
MK veterans illegally occupy vacant housing in protest of their poor treatment since the end of apartheid.
On 29 October 2014, a service delivery demonstration degenerates into looting and violence. Both foreign nationals and South African citizens are targeted. [size=no report]

Residents of the Rholihlahla informal settlement protest outside the Port Elizabeth City Hall demanding to be relocated to serviced sites while they wait for RDP houses.Their relocation from the Missionvale informal settlement to Joe Slovo came to a halt following allegations that the relocation list was manipulated to favour DA affiliated residents.
Orange Farm residents barricaded roads and burnt tyres demanding jobs at the opening of a new mall in the area. Some residents clashed violently with the malls security staff.
