Residents of Majakaneng riot for a second day and burn a truck.
Residents of Modderspruit riot for a sixth day. The demonstrators accuse a nearby mine of failing to provide employment for locals as promised.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of SATAWU protest outside the Huguenot Tunnel, a toll road, over insufficient wages and poor working conditions.
Residents of Blackburn village barricade the road and stone cars during a service-delivery protest. The demonstrators claim they have been without electricity for days.
Letlhabile residents picket outside Brits Magistrates Court during the trial of two women accused of burning a teenager to death. The demonstrators demand that the court not grant the suspects bail.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Over 1000 SA Municipal Workers Union members march to Port Elizabeth to hand over a list of demands, including he reinstatement of a scarce-skills allowance, the lifting of a three-year moratorium on filling vacancies, and the provision of land by the municipality to employees on which to build housing.

On 9 July 2015, a vigilante group consisting of Congolese, Zimbabweans and other foreign nationals badly beat a man suspected of robbing and murdering a Congolese man before handing the suspect over to the police. The murder of the Congolese man is believed to be a criminally rather than politically motivated killing. [size=no report]

Residents of Ficksburg march to the police station and demand action after four people are murdered in the township. The residents threaten to engage in vigilante violence if the police are unable to deal with criminals effectively.
Members of the Islamic Unity Convention march to parliament to demand that the government separate ties with Israel and push for the release of all Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails.

Upset residents try to hand over a memorandum to the municipal manager. After the manager is found not to be present the residents start to throw stones at the mayor prompting a response by the police. A policeman is critically injured after he is run over by a bakkie driven by protesters trying to access the municipal offices.
Residents of Philippi stone and chase members of the fire and rescue crew after they arrive late to put out a shack fire, resulting in the destruction of 8 dwellings. No serious injuries reported.

Residents of Ga-Mampuru block the road with burning tyres. The demonstrators are protesting against the lack of tarred roads and unemployment. The residents are also demanding employment at the local mines.
Vigilantes burn and kill a man accused of stealing a television.
Residents of Ga-Mampuru continue to riot and burn a truck to use as a road block in a protest against the lack of employment opportunities and tarred roads.
The IFPs ward chairman in KwaMashu is gunned down by unknown assailants after leaving a branch meeting.
A truck is burnt by protesters in Steelpoort. The action is believed to be related to the protests in Ga-Mampuru concerning the lack of employment and tarred roads.
Residents of Hout Bay burn down a derelict council building which had been housing homeless individuals. There had recently been a spate of crimes in the area surrounding the building.

column6: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards
column17: Prison guards at Losperfontein Correctional Prison torture and assault prisoners after an inmate escapes.

A man is assassinated by unknown assailants in ongoing political violence at Glebelands Hostel. The root of the conflict is allegedly due to competition between different block committees at the hostel.
ANC members, led by a local ANC councillor attack EFF activists and smash their vehicles with bricks. There are no reports of serious injuries among the activists.
Residents of Soweto throw stones and clash with the police when the police try to intervene to prevent a vigilante killing
Residents of Soweto stone a suspected thief to death
Members of the Highflats Taxi Association blockade the small town of Jolivet to protest against the takeover of their route.
Over 50 protesters occupy the stage of the Sand du Plessis Theatre and protest causing a production of Liewe Heksie: Flower Power to end prematurely. The reason for the protest is unknown.
Hundreds of protesters opposing the development of the Clairwood Logistics Park demonstrate outside the Department of Environmental Affairs.
Communities surrounding Steelpoort block the road and protest over the poor quality of their roads disrupting the operations of the nearby mines.

Residents of Lwamondo riot after the discovery of a mutilated body in a tree. The rioters blockade the road and exort money from passing motorists and burn down the houses of individuals accused of the murder.

Protesters from Barcelona informal settlement block the N2 highway for nearly three hours with burning tyres. The protesters accuse Ward councilor Mzwakhe Nqavashe of nepotism in the distribution of cleaning contracts for the area.
A second man within a week is assassinated by an unknown group in Glebelands Hostel.
A man accused of witchcraft is fatally lynched and set alight by a vigilante mob.
ANC members allegedly attack and assault EFF supporters during a community meeting in Hebron.

The bodyguard of KwaZulu-Natal Premier Senzo Mchunu is found murdered. The murder is attributed to a factional fight within the ANC in the province with opposing factions accusing Mchunu of involvement in the fatal car crash that killed regional ANC boss and rival Thulani Mashaba.
Communities surrounding Steelpoort continue to demonstrate and barricade the road and protest over the poor quality of their roads disrupting the operations of the nearby mines.
Undercover police pursuing a hijacked truck and staff from a car tracking company are shot at by the South African Defence Forces. The soldiers allegedly detain and assault the police officers.
Several taxi operators from the South Coast block the road near Park Rynie in protest against an apparent takeover of routes by Durbans Sonke Long Distance Association.
Police use rubber bullets and teargas to disperse rioting residents demanding that the prepaid water system installed last year be removed.
Another truck is burnt during a protest by Ga-Mampuru residents over the lack of employment opportunities. The demonstrators accuse the local government of failing to secure mining jobs for locals.

Parents from Leruleng village near Mokopane protest and disrupt the learning at a school in a neighbouring village. The protesters accuse Limpopo education department and a mining company of reneging on an initial agreement to build a school within their village.
Protesters protest and erect barricades for a third day in a protest over the poor quality of the roads.

""The Queer Revolution"" staged a march to protest the refusal of the Vice-President of the University of Cape Towns Students Representative Council (SRT) to resign following the publishing of a homophobic Facebook status she wrote.

Vuwani residents riot and burn down the house of Sanco leader Calvin Mathebula. Vuwani and surrounding villages, populated mainly by Venda-speaking people, are refusing to be incorporated into a proposed municipality which will include Malamulele.
Parents protest outside an unused temporary school in Dunoon. The protesters are concerned that their children may be unable to get an education due to a lack of available places in existing schools.
Approximately 60 people burnt tyres on roads near the Cape Town International Airport in a service delivery protest.
Parents blockade the entrance to a school in East London and demand that a substitute teacher at the school be made permanent by the department of education.
Students at Elsenburg Agricultural Training Institute near Stellenbosch protest and demand that classes be taught in English as they are unable to follow lectures given in Afrikaans.

EFF supporters march to the provincial government offices to protest against what it termed high municipal and electricity rates. The demonstrators demand that the government subsidise basic services or face future disruptions by the party.

Demonstrators from the EFF and ANC protest outside Rustenburg court and face off against each other during the trial of an ANC activist accused of damaging EFF vehicles. There are no reports of violence between the two groups.
A suspect accused of carrying out an assassination in Glebelands hostel is severely tortured by police.
Residents of Pietermaritzberg riot for a second time in a week over the installation of prepaid water metres. Police disperse the rioters with teargas.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: A COSAS led march turns into a riot when demonstrators begin to loot from local vendors. The police disperse the rioters while some vendors fight to protect their businesses.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: Students engaging in the COSAS march clash with foreign vendors and try to loot their stores. Some vendors defend their property with weapons and firearms.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in Queenstown demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in King Williams town demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in Port Elizbeth demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in Maluti demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in East London demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of NEHAWU stage a picket in Aliwal North demanding that the head of the Economic Development, Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department be removed from his post. The grievances include insufficient equipment, reversals of employee benefits, centralisation of their budget, and ""casualisation"" of workers.
A man caught stealing from a house is attacked by a vigilante mob. The victim survives the attack.
Three individuals accused of taking part in a robbery are attacked by community members of Ha-Makhuvha village. Two of the victims die of their wounds while a third remains in critical condition.
Farmers and their families protest in central Pretoria and demand more action from the authorities in solving a recent spate of farm murders.
Residents of Nwamitwa block the road with burning debris and clash with police during a service delivery protest. The police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets.

Supporters of the two rivals both claiming inheritance of the Nazareth Baptist Church clash outside Durban High Court with weapons. The two factions are deadlocked over who will claim ownership of the church.

Police clash with rioters in Port Elizabeths northern areas. The riots follow a prolonged strike by teachers to demand better school infrastructure. During the riots there are reports of gunfire and police firing live ammunition at rioters.
Vlakfontein residents block the highway with burning debris for unknown reasons.
The supporters of two rivals both claiming ownership of Nazareth Baptist Church clash for a second day in the centre of Durban.
Students at Stellenbosch University protest and demand that lectures be given in English rather than Afrikaans.
Riots occur for a second day in Port Elizabeths northern areas as residents clash with police and protest against the prolonged clusure of schools by striking teachers.
Taxi drivers march against the Go George public transportation system which they claim will put them out of business.
Residents of Dobsonville in Soweto riot over power cuts and issues in the electricity supply. Demonstrators block the road with stones and debris.
Residents of Dobsonville riot for a second day over power cuts and issues with the electricity supply.
Walter Sisulu University students march to protest against insufficient funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme and to demand the dismissal of a lecturer accused of racism.

Workers in Pretorias Operation Vat Alles, which cleans prioritised wards in the city, down tools and protest against unpaid salaries and the use of ANC members to intimidate those who disagree with the mayor.
Pupils from the Chicken Farm area are chased away from school by local residents.

Parents and pupils march to the education department in Mdantsane after pupils from the Chicken Farm neighbourhood are chased away from their schools by residents of a neighbouring area. The demonstrators demand that a school be built in their area.

2 security guards assaulted a student at Morningside High School in Port Elizabeth. A teacher attempted to intervene but was prevented, while another student who attempted to stop them was peppersprayed and beaten.
Residents of Makhado march to the police station and demand an increased police presence after a string of killings in the area.
Pupils from two areas at the Leshman High School clashed after a community gathering, causing teachers to flee the school.

column7: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
column17: A Pagad protest came under attack from alleged gangsters who threw stones, bottles and fired shots at them. One police officer who was escorting the protest was injured by a rock and a number of vehicles were damaged.
About 300 residents marched through the town to demand a family/child violence protection and sexual offences unit for their police force.
Protesters blocked the R72 road with burning tires, while police threatened to use force to remove them until provincial officials arrived. It was not reported what they were protesting about.
The chairperson of the Greater Stilfontein Taxi Association was shot once in the head through his living room window by unidentified gunmen.
Residents of Tshifudi, Tshidzini and Tshaulu blockade the road and riot over police inaction after a series of ritual murders take place in the local area.
Residents of Tshifudi, Tshidzini and Tshaulu blockade the road and riot over police inaction after a series of ritual murders take place in the local area.
Residents of Tshifudi, Tshidzini and Tshaulu blockade the road and riot over police inaction after a series of ritual murders take place in the local area.
Residents of Namakgale protested, barricaded roads and burnt vehicles between Namakgale and Phalaborwa over unemployment. The protests paralyzed activities in the town.
Local residents protested outside a courthouse against crimes against children as a case related to the killing of a child was being examined.
A woman from Johannesburg started a long walk to Mahikeng with 3 other women to draw attention to women and child abus.
Residents of Dikhibidung informal settlement stone municipal vehicles and demand employment at the local sewage plant.

Members of the South African Municipal Workers Union (SAMWU) protested in the Alfred Nzo municipality district of Kokstad and staged sit-ins related to perceived improper management. They also blockedroads with rocks and burning tires.
A taxi owner was shot at close range by two unidentified gunmen while in his taxi outside the Ramaphosa taxi rank in Boksburg. Another man was injured. The reasonf or the shooting was not reported.

Residents of the Mzimhlophe Hostel rioted over power outages, including throwing stones at vehicles and blocking roads. Police arrived and attempted to disperse the protesters, including firing rubber bullets. The residents also set a fire engine on fire.

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Students (South Africa)
column17: A meeting of the student wing of the EFF at the University of Johannesburg was violently dispersed by heavily armed riot police (including AK47s) who allegedly assaulted the students after warning them to disperse.
Violent protests occurred in Steelpoort where residents burnt trucks and blocked villagers employed by the mines from going to work.
Rioters set two vehicles on fire and damaged 4 others during violent protests over a proposed new municipal boundary.
Parents of children attending Tyburn Primary School in Chatsworth protested after an alleged rape of two boys at the school was reported.
Protests occurred in the area of Matsatseng in the Mahikeng cluster, during which police were present.
EFF members attacked an ""infamous snake-eating church"", set a tent on fire, and beat some of its members as they fled.
Hout Bay residents protested against growing insecurity. They marched from Hangberg to Imizamo Yethu.
Tires were burned and roads were blocked by people from Sonop near Brits who demanded electricity.

Ginsberg township, outside of King Williams Town, saw demonstrations where about 600 angry residents blocked roads and burnt tires to protest against a lack of service delivery. Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the protesters, who threw stones in retaliation.

Residents in Bona-Bona and Morokweng protest and demand that the road between the two villages is tarred. The protests lead to the closure of four schools but no reports of violence or destruction of property were reported.
Residents of Dikhibidung informal settlement barricade the road and destroy a water tanker. The residents are demanding employment at the local sewage works.

Residents in Bona-Bona and Morokweng protest and demand that the road between the two villages is tarred. The protests lead to the closure of four schools but no reports of violence or destruction of property were reported.
Parents and pupils protested outside the Vukile Tshwethe High School in Keiskammahoek over the dilapidated state of infrastructure at the school.
About 100 people took part in service delivery protests rocked KwaDabeka.
Ugie residents violently protest, demanding employment at a local lumber company. Date unknown - source dated 18/08, reports it occurred ""last week.""
Residents of Dikhibidung informal settlement continue their protest and set an ambulance on fire. The residents are demanding employment at the local sewage works.
Residents in Bona-Bona and Morokweng protest for a second day and demand a tarred road between the two settlements.
100 unemployed shack dwellers of Daluxolo informal settlement in Mdantsane NU6 barricaded the Qumza highway demanding proper houses.
Residents in Bona-Bona and Morokweng protest for a second day and demand a tarred road between the two settlements.
Residents of Sonop near Brits barricaded internal roads to demand electricity for a second day.

5 men were arrested of public violence and looting during a protest related to service delivery in the Walmer area of Port Elizabeth. The protesters blocked roads and threw stones at vehicles belonging to the police and others. At least one police officer was injured.
Service delivery riots continue in Walmer with rioters clashing with police.
Two men accused of being gangsters are stoned to death in the Hout Bay township of Imizamo Yethu.
A march took place in Sekororo, near Tzaneen, in protest over the suspension of the municipal manager.
Thousands of Imizamo Yethu residents march through the township and confiscate weapons from suspected gangsters.
Lesseyton residents closed the N6 road with burning tyres in protest against the alleged non-payment of contractors involved in a housing project by Cape Town.
Hundreds of Democratic Alliance members protested in front of the Department of Home Affairs against visa regulations which are allegedly harming the tourism industry.
NU29 residents in Motherwell set fire to two municipal bakkies. The riot is due to alleged missallocation of houses.
Protesters in Addo march and call for a canal where a number of local children have died to be closed off from the public.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Mourners demonstrate on the anniversary of the Marikana killings. Many of the demonstrators are AMCU members.

Ugie residents and employees at PG Bison riot and demand that PG Bison company to employ 4 500 young people and contribute on social responsibility programs atUgie and Maclear. The police respond with rubber bullets.
NU29 residents in Motherwell burn down a community hall to protest against the alleged missallocation of houses.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members picket outside the offices of Limpopo MEC Jerry Ndou after handing over a memorandum. The union organised protests daily from 17-21 of August.

Security guards at Chromax mine fire live ammo at EFF and community protesters demanding the compliance of the mine to the corporate social responsibility agreements and the provision of training and jobs to the local community. A community leader is injured during the protest.
Ugie residents and employees at PG Bison continue to riot. The police respond with rubber bullets.

Police fire rubber bullets at rioting teachers outside Roodepoort Primary School. The school has been at a centre of a debacle in which the appointment of a black head teacher is opposed by some coloured parents who claim that the appointment was motivated by corruption rather than merit.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members picket outside the offices of Limpopo MEC Jerry Ndou after handing over a memorandum. The union organised protests daily from 17-21 of August.
Vigilantes in Soweto assault a Mozambican man accused of thievery. The police intervene preventing the mob from lynching the man.
Small, medium and micro enterprises closed the municipal offices and other projects in Uitenhage, complaining that they do not benefit from projects in the town.
EFF students clash with non-politically aligned students at Wits University.
A small group of sex workers gathered on the steps of the Western Cape High Court to protest against the delays in the murder case against acclaimed artist and murder accused, Zwelethu Mthethwa.

NU29 residents in Motherwell continue to riot against the alleged missallocation of houses in the area. NU12 residents face off with the rioters a form a human shield around a primary school to prevent the NU29 residents from burning it down. No reported incidents of violence during the stand off.

The EFF march in solidarity with Roodepoort residents who oppose the appointment of the head teacher by Roodepoort Primary School. The protesters claim that the heads appointment was moviated by corruption.
Suspected taxi drivers burn Go George public transport buses. The taxi drivers complain that the service will put them out of business.
NU12 residents continue to form human shields around various buildings in Motherwell to prevent NU29 residents from destroying property.
Residents of Enseleni protest against blasts at nearby mines and quarries which they say damage their homes.
Residents of Ga-Mampuru burn debris and demand the government build more roads in the area.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members picket outside the offices of Limpopo MEC Jerry Ndou after handing over a memorandum. The union organised protests daily from 17-21 of August.
Employees of Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa demonstrate outside the parastatals head office demanding the reinstatement of former chief executive Lucky Montana.

200 residents from Bucula, Ngoqelo, Mvilo and Egoli villages blockade the road outside Ngqueleni. The villagers had previously visited their ward councilor to ask why their villages had not been electrified only for the councilor to say that she was unaware of the villagers existance.
Residents of Magqazeni village blockade the R72 road for more than three hours in a service delivery protest
University of Cape Town students protest against the universities investments in Lonmin which the protesters accuse of being complicit in the Marikana Killing.

EFF leader Malema leads villagers from the settlements around Burgersfort in a march to hand over a memorandum to the Modikwa Platinum Mine. The memorandum calls for more investment by mining firms in the local area.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members picket outside the offices of Limpopo MEC Jerry Ndou after handing over a memorandum. The union organised protests daily from 17-21 of August.
Close to 1000 angry Buffalo City Metro ANC members and supporters march to the parties regional offices demanding the regional structure be dissolved.
Residents riot in Burgersfort and burn vehicles. The reason for the riot is unknown.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Students (South Africa)
column17: EFF-aligned students protest and disrupt a SRC elections debate at Wits University.
A man is severely beaten and hospitalised by members of the Bapo Ba Mogale Tribal Authority for opposing a deal between mining giant Lonmin and the tribal authorities.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members picket outside the offices of Limpopo MEC Jerry Ndou after handing over a memorandum. The union organised protests daily from 17-21 of August.
EFF march to Modikwa Platinum Mine to hand over a memorandum demanding that the mine provide more social investment in the local community.
Police fire stun grenades at rioting George residents who are protesting against the impounding of their taxis.
Demonstrators engage in a silent protest to show solidarity with rape survivors and to demand greater access to healthcare for survivors.
A mob attacks a man accused of sexually assaulting an elderly resident and attempts to necklace the suspect. The police intervene before the man is killed.
Residents clash with police and set police vehicles on fire after they prevent a vigilante mob from killing a man accused of sexually assaulting an elderly woman.
Residents burn down a councillors house after accusing him of diverting materials meant to build affordable houses in order to build an extension on his home.
Residents of Zebediela in Limpopo protest against poor service delivery. Some residents barricade the road during the protest.
A man suspected of starting a shack fire which led to the death of several people is burnt to death by a mob.
Motherwell residents march to the centre of Port Elizabeth and demand to know when the RDP houses promised to them will be built.
Residents of Langa barricade the road with burning debris during a riot over the allocation process for a local hostel transformation project.
Residents of Klipheuwel riot and destroy vehicles during a protest over the lack of electricity.
Residents of Wittedrift throw stones at the police, who respond with stun grenades, during a protest over the lack of housing.
Activists protest in Pretoria against the governments plans for nuclear power.

column7: TAC: Treatment Action Campaign; EE: Equal Education; SJC: Social Justice Coalition; Right2Know
column17: Members of various social justice organisations to demand more police resources for Khayelitsha and more equity in the distribution of police personnel.
Residents of Langa riot for a second day over the allocation process for a local hostel transformation project.

Farm workers at Worley Commons farm set alight to a portion of a farm to protest against alleged abuse by the farms management. Alleged abuses include cutting off water and illegally impounding animals as disciplinary penalities.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column9: PASMA: Pan Africanist Student Movement of Azania
column17: Students aligned with the EFF and PASMA violently clash at the Tshwane University of Technologys Soshanguve campus ahead of the SRC elections during a speech by EFF leader Julius Malema.
Residents of Klipheuwel protest over the lack of electricity in their settlement.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: SASCO students at the Tshwane University of Technology throw stones at EFF students during a speech by leader Julius Malema. The EFF students then clash with the SASCO students.
Dismissed workers at the Avon Power Peaking Plant at Shakaskraal riot and severely assault the projects contracts director. The attack hospitalised the victim.
Farm workers at Worley Commons farm protest and hand in a memorandum of complaints concerning abuses by the farms management.

Students occupy Rhodes University council chambers to protest against means-testing for access to accommodation over the break period. The protesters reject the requirement that students must show they met the criteria for vacation accommodation before they were accepted.
Residents assault and damage the house of a man suspected of killing a local taxi driver. The homeowner responds with gunfire causing the rioters to flee.

Owners of small-medium enterprises block the road with their vehicles and debris and demand a 30% stake in a R200-million road project. The police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets and tear gas.
Municipal workers push past police to disrupt a council meeting. The protesters allege that they have not been paid their months wages and demand to be offered permanent posts with the council.

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column9: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: SASCO and ANCYL students lay siege to Tshwane University of Technology halls in Pretoria and severely injure two EFF students.
COPE members march outside Thokoza police station to protest against alleged corrupt conduct by local police officers. The police intervene and arrest six COPE members.

A vigilante mob attacks a man accused of stabbing another resident. Police clash with the mob in an attempt to stop the lynching but are driven back after being pelted with stones. The police eventually manage to get the victim to hospital where he dies of his injuries.

A vigilante mob attacks a man accused of stabbing another resident. Police clash with the mob in an attempt to stop the lynching but are driven back after being pelted with stones. The police eventually manage to get the victim to hospital where he dies of his injuries.

A man recently released from prison is burnt to death by a mob in what is believed to be a vigilante attack. Two of the victims associates escaped with injuries. One of the associates later died in hospital.
Rioters block the road connecting Polokwane and Botlokwa. The reason for the demonstration is unknown.
Police fire rubber bullets at rioting residents of Vuwani. The residents are resisting the incorporation of Vuwani into a new municipality.

Parents protest after primary school pupils are robbed and assaulted by high school pupils in Hankey. The younger pupils have moved to the high school building while renovations are being done to the primary school.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: EFFSC members at Elsenburg Agricultural Training Institute lock students out of their classes during a protest against the use of Afrikaans in lectures.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU members picket outside the trial of seven rapists and demand that justice be done.
The Black Students Movement toyi-toyi and disrupt a senate meeting at Rhodes University. The BSM are demanding faster transformation at the university.
Residents of Burlington Heights block the road with burning debris during a service delivery protest.
Residents of Cato Manor block the road with burning debris during a service delivery protest.
Residents of an informal settlement in Durban block the road with burning debris during a service delivery protest.
UNISA students protest demanding the immediate reopening of 18 recently closed exam centres and the removal of a newly introduced acceptance fee.

Informal residents of Langa violently protest and demand that they should benefit from a new housing scheme in Langa. The riot began after the members of the city council fail to show up to a meeting aimed at resolving the conflict.

Taxi drivers block roads with their vehicles during a protest against a decision by taxi associations in Polokwane that Thohoyandou drivers should off-load commuters destined for Gauteng in order for the commuters to take connecting taxis.

Residents of villages surrounding Mokopane including Ga-Molekane, Mogalakwena, Skiming, Sekuruwe and Rooibok blockade the roads, burn trucks and clash with police from Monday 31st of August to Thursday 3rd of September. The demonstrators demand that production at the local mines stop until the companies invest in the local area and hire local residents.

Parents protest for a second day after primary school pupils are robbed and assaulted by high school pupils in Hankey. The younger pupils have moved to the high school building while renovations are being done to the primary school.

Residents of Mapela protest over the lack of consultation on mining projects between mines, the traditional leadership and the community. Protesters block roads and halt activity at the mine. The police respond with rubber bullets.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Students at the Elsenburg Agricultural Training Institute protest against the use of Afrikaans in lectures and accuse the university of being an outpost of white supremacy. During the protests students belonging to the EFF sjambok and injure non protesting students.

Residents of villages surrounding Mokopane including Ga-Molekane, Mogalakwena, Skiming, Sekuruwe and Rooibok blockade the roads, burn trucks and clash with police from Monday 31st of August to Thursday 3rd of September. The demonstrators demand that production at the local mines stop until the companies invest in the local area and hire local residents.
Teachers and different groups of students engage in fist fights with each other during a protest over the use of Afrikaans in lectures at Elsenburg Agricultural Training Institute.
Residents of Langa continue to riot for a second day and damage property.
Residents of Vuwani continue to riot against the planned inclusion into a newly demarcated municipality. The rioters loot and damage property.
An ex-Zimbabwean captain accused in Zimbabwe of plotting a coup against Mugabe is beaten by unidentified men, presumbed to be Zimbabweans, in downtown Johannesburg.

Residents of villages surrounding Mokopane including Ga-Molekane, Mogalakwena, Skiming, Sekuruwe and Rooibok blockade the roads, burn trucks and clash with police from Monday 31st of August to Thursday 3rd of September. The demonstrators demand that production at the local mines stop until the companies invest in the local area and hire local residents.
Protests continue at the Elsenburg Agricultural Training Institute over the use of Arikaans in lectures. There are reports of black and white students engaging in fist fights with each other.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANC and ANCYL members march to the Mdantsane branch of First National Bank (FNB) following an expose which revealed how ANC membership forms were rigged by an employee of the branch. The marchers hand over a memorandum demanding a public apology by the bank and the handing over of information on fradulant activity to the police.

A group allied to exiled Rwandan general Kayumba Nyamwasa held a peaceful demonstration at the Rwandan High Commission in South Africa on 2 September against a move by Rwandas parliament to amend the constitution and lift term limits, enabling President Paul Kagame to run for another term after 2017.

column7: AfriForum Organization; SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: University of Pretoria students belonging to Afriforum, EFF and SASCO protest against alleged election rigging after the DA wins the SRC elections.
Residents riot against police inaction and blockade the road following the discovery of a body of an 18-year-old woman allegedly killed in a ritual urder.

Police fire rubber bullets into a crowd of protesting students from the University of South Africa during a demonstration in Durban, causing severe injuries. The students were protesting against new fees and the closure of exam halls.

Students armed with sticks and rocks protest at University of KwaZulu-Natals Edgewood. The demonstrators argued that the university management was not allowing the student voice to be heard. The students were dispersed by police.
Rioters in Vuwani clash with police during a protest against Vuwanis incorporation into a new municipality.
Municipal workers from the Expanded Public Works Programme burn down municipal buildings and vehicles during a protest over wages.

Residents of villages surrounding Mokopane including Ga-Molekane, Mogalakwena, Skiming, Sekuruwe and Rooibok blockade the roads, burn trucks and clash with police from Monday 31st of August to Thursday 3rd of September. The demonstrators demand that production at the local mines stop until the companies invest in the local area and hire local residents.
Residents protest over blackouts and powercuts.
Grade 12 pupils riot after they are not given their reports meaning that they are unable to submit university applications. Police intervene and arrest some of the rioters.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: The South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) has instructed its 256 000 members to boycott any involvement in the Annual National Assessments. SADTU argue that the annual exams are unnecessary.
Rioters in Vuwani set alight to police vehicles during a protest against the towns planned incorporation into a new municipality.

Police fire upon at rioting residents resulting in six serious injuries. There are contradicting accounts concerning whether the police used rubber bullets or live ammunition. The rioters are demanding more investment and consultation by local mining companies.
A man accused of stealing a wallet and stabbing a patron at a shebeen is beaten to death by community members.
Police allegedly fire upon rioting villagers in the area around Mokopane resulting in injuries. The rioters are demanding more investment from the local mines and consultation on future operations.
20 buses are burnt during a riot in Marapong settlement in Lephalale. The riots are supposedly linked to mass layoffs and alleged nepotism in hirings at Medupi power station.
Villagers of Ndindani block the roads with debris and demand that their roads be tarred.
Villagers of Khakhala block the roads with debris and demand that their roads be tarred.
Villagers of Hlomela in Giyani Local Municipality block the roads with debris and demand that their roads be tarred.
Villagers of Mahlathi block the roads with debris and demand that their roads be tarred.
Two suspected criminals are beaten and set alight by vigilantes in Mfuleni.
Villagers of Gawula block the roads with debris and demand that their roads be tarred.

Security guards patrolling Blyvooruitzicht mine outside Carletonville on the far West Rand came under fire from an army of more than 100 illegal miners. There were no reported casualties from the gunfight.
Over 1000 pupils march through iSimangaliso Wetland Park to protest against rhino poaching.
Rioters continue to burn vehicles in Lephalale. The riots are connected to mass layoffs and alleged nepotism in the hiring process at Medupi power station.
Residents of Pienaar in Mpumalanga block roads with debris and protest against a construction company which they accuse of not employing local people.

Parents of children who had been attending Roodepoort Primary School march to the offices of Gauteng Premier David Makhura and protest against his reopening of the school without their consultation. The school has been at the centre of a dispute concerning the alleged appointment of a head teacher due to race rather than merit.
Protesters demonstrate in Mdantsane and complain the RDP houses they have been provided with have not been constructed properly and have been built with substandard materials.

Villagers in Mogalakwena municipality block the roads leading to the Amplat platinum mine and intimidate motorists. The rioters are demanding the mine invest more in the local community and consult communities on proposed changes and operations.
Rioters in Missionvale continue to protest and demand houses with electricity and plumbing. The protesters burn tyres and clash with the police who disperse them with rubber bullets.
200 Uitenhage residents protest outside the Port Elizabeth High Court. The residents are facing eviction from the land they occupy by the municipal authorities.
Imizamo Yethu residents march to the police station to protest about crime in their area.

Community members in the Mogalakwena municipality burn down a school and riot. The rioters claim that some elected community members are being left out of peace talks with Mineral Resources Minister Ngoako Ramatlhodi who is mediating between mining firms and protesting community members demanding more investment and consultation from the mines.
Residents of Missionvale barricade the road and demand to speak to the provincial premier. The demonstrators are demanding RDP houses with electricity and sanitation.
Residents block the road with burning debris during a protest over the erratic electricity supply.

Unemployed youth riot in Ramokokastad and vandilise the office of North West premier Supra Mahumapelo. The youth demand to be employed at the local mine. The police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets.

column7: SACCAWU: South African Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers Union; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: 200 SACCAWU members protest outside the Eastern Cape Development Corporation headquarters in East London demanding a 10% salary increase and an increase in housing allowances.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Members of the SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) marched to the Civic Centre demanding that the City employ expanded public works programme (EPWP) workers permanently
Rhodes University students, academics and workers protest and demand more transformation at the university and increased staff wages.

Students at King Sabata Dalindyebo Technical Vocational Education and Training College protest over changes to their National Student Financial Aid Scheme allowances and violently clash with university security guards.
Members of the DA protest outside the closed Kempton Park hospital and demand that the hospital be re-opened.

Picketing workers at Tormin mine clash with police resulting in both police and demonstrator injuries. The workers were striking over wage cuts, unfair dismissals and workplace racism. The miners are affiliated with the National Union of Mineworkers.
On 10 September 2015, two women accused of practicing witchcraft were shot in their homes by local residents in Dindala.
Residents of Potchefstroom protest against the proposed merger of the Tlokwe local municipality and the Ventersdorp local municipality.
Rioters burn a municipal building during a demonstration against the proposed merger of the Tlokwe local municipality and the Ventersdorp local municipality.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: ANC and EFF politicians march in King Williams Town to commemorate the anniversary of Steve Bikos death at the hands of the apartheid regime.

Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Westvile campus riot and burn down an administrative building. The students were protesting against an increase in registration fees and changes to the marks needed to qualify for funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme.
Vigilantes kill three youths who allegedly belong to the OVL gang. The gang has been responsible for a spate of murders and robberies in the area.

An ANC ward committee member and branch secretary are killed execution-style by unknown assailants. The murder is believed to be politically motivated as local politicians have already begun campaigning for next years municipal elections.

Protesters lock municipal staff and ANC Tshwane regional executive committee inside the mayoral offices. The demonstrators are part of a national public works program and are demanding the payment of owed wages and permanent employment.
Residents of Clare Estate barricade the road during a service delivery protest demanding electricity. The police disperse the rioters.
Police destroy illegal shacks owned by informal residents occupying municipal land. Backyarders armed with petrol-bombs protest in response, leading to multiple arrests.
Residents of Vastrap informal settlement in Port Elizabeth torch a bus during a protest to demand better housing.

Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Westvile campus riot and clash with police and university security. The students were protesting against an increase in registration fees and changes to the marks needed to qualify for funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme.
Residents riot after the rape and murder of a 14-year-old boy. The rioters torch a police van during the demonstration.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Employees at Ceres Fruit Growers riot and destroy a wharehouse. The demonstrators were demanding a 12.5 percent in wage increases and a share in company profits. The protest was organised by the Food and Allied Workers Union.
Three youths accused of being criminals are stoned and hacked to death by a crowd of vigilantes.

Over 600 students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus riot over an increase in registration fees and changes to the marks needed to qualify for funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme. The protesters throw petrol bombs at the police who respond with rubber bullets.
Students at the Vaal University of Technology protest against the murder of two students by criminals.

Disgruntled school governing body (SGB) members and parents protest and demand that the principal of Parliament Street Primary school be dismissed. The demonstrators accuse the head of dictatorial practices.
Residents riot after the rape and murder of a 14-year-old boy. During the riot, a vigilante mob lynches and burns an alleged criminal. Another man is assaulted by the mob and later dies in hospital.
Residents of the Corrie Sanders informal settlement march to the Madibeng local municipality and demand that the municipality buy the land they occupy from private owners.
Community members burn down a shack belonging to the mother of suspected OVL gang members.
Residents of Vrischgewaagt, near Delareyville, protest against rising crime and sexual violence in the area.

Unknown assailants firebomb an Intercape bus resulting in 32 injuries and two deaths. Allegations of involvement have been levelled at the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa due to ongoing negotiations with Intercape over retrenchments and downsizing.

Residents from Mthatha West and KwaLindile try to occupy and cultivate the 300ha Bedford Farm just outside Mthatha. After one of the occupiers is arrested, residents from the two areas protest outside the police station demanding his release.
Over 100 students from universities, colleges and high schools march to the magistrates court in King Williams Town to protest against sexual violence targeting students.
The Rhodes Memorial in Cape Town is defaced by unknown perpetrators. The act of vandalism has occurred amid a string of attacks against culturally significant monuments.

Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus continue to riot and clash with police. The students were originally protesting against an increase in registration fees and changes to the marks needed to qualify for funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme.
A man accused of taking part in the killing of two police officers is detained and severely tortured in custody.
Pupils at Port St Johns secondary school burn tyres outside the school gates and demand that their headmaster be removed. The pupils accuse the headmaster of practicing witchcraft.
Parents in Polokwane hold a vigil outside the home of the MEC for education in a bid to force the provincial government to supply furniture to their children's school.
A vigilante mob assaults a suspected thief during wider protests in Nebo. The victim is saved by police.

Rioting taxi drivers riot and violently clash with police in Mthathas central business district. The drivers were protesting against plans by the municipality to move the taxi rank. On-duty firemen are seriously injured when the rioters pelt them with stones.
Rioting taxi drivers riot and violently clash with police in Mthathas central business district. The drivers were protesting against plans by the municipality to move the taxi rank.
Residents of Nebo burn the mobile rooms of a nursing school at St Ritas hospital. The villagers allege that the school only teaches people from Polokwane while locals are overlooked.
Protesters use burning debris and blockades to prevent the council and police from relocating seven families to the settlement of Wolwerivier. The families had applied to be relocated.

Residents at Wolwerivier protest against the relocation of people from other overcrowded settlements to the area. The police respond by firing rubber bullets and beating the protesters resulting in serior injuries.

column7: Students (South Africa); SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: SANCO lead a protest in Stellenbosch University againstthe apparent lack of transformation at the institution and its language policy.
Two suspected drug dealers are attacked by vigilantes after ignoring warnings to leave Masiphumelele. One of the victims dies.
Residents of Hout Bay protest against the closure of a fish factory which they say will cost local jobs.
Delft residents protest outside the police station and call for more police to be brought to the area to combat crime.
Police try to intervene to prevent vigilante violence but are stopped by burning debris and gunfire. The police respond by firing stun grenades and teargas into the crowd.
Demonstrators march to Mamelodi West police station to show solidarity with police officers and protest against the rising incidence of police deaths on-duty.
ANC supporters and members sing and chant to disrupt a live television debate between the main parties in Port Elizabeth.
A peaceful protest is held in Munsieville. The reason for the protest is not confirmed.

column7: BDS: Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions Movement
column17: Between 500 and 1,000 BDS protest outside the Grand West casino in Cape Town against US singer Pharrell Williams. The demonstrators were protesting against the singers affiliation with Woolworths with sells Israeli goods.

Taxi drivers protest outside Durban central police station over the arrest of hundreds of taxi drivers and the impounding of their vehicles. The police have initiated a crackdown on the taxi industry to curb taxi-related violence and the use of certain routes without permits.
Students at the Tshwane University of Technology burn tyres and destroy property during a protest over inadequate accommodation and stale food. The police are deployed to disperse the rioters.
Khoisan demonstrators destroy a bench dedicated to Khoisan historical figure Krotoa van Meerhoff on the basis that the bench is disrepectful. They are immediately arrested by police.

Hundreds of protesters march to the municipality to demand jobs at the R34 road construction site. Youths accusing the municipality of nepotism in the appointment of people on a road construction project severely beat and hospitalise municipal employees.
A bus is torched during ongoing protests at University of KwaZulu-Natal. The students are rioting against issues concerning funding and fees.
A man accused of murdering a woman in a guesthouse is severely beaten by police while in custody.
A municipal bus was stoned in Reservoir Hills by suspected striking taxi drivers. 12 people were treated for severe injuries after the attack.
A tavern owner accused of being a gang member is beaten and burnt to death by local residents.
Angry residents protest outside a construction site of a local housing project in Mdantsane.
Three university security guards are injured by rioting students at University of KwaZulu-Natal. The students are rioting against issues concerning funding and fees.
Residents of Heidedal in Bloefomtein kill an alleged gangster.
Two men caught using drugs are beaten to death by community members.
Non-violent activity: Deputy Speaker of the Eastern Cape Provincial Legislature, Ms Bulelwa Tunyiswa, is shot at by an off-duty policeman. Ms Tunyiswa is uninjured.
Residents of Magatle in Limpopo dig a trench across the motorway during a service delivery protest.
Two men are stoned to death by community members. The two victims were allegedly associates of a man accused of robbing local residents.
Westenburg residents riot, destroy property and clash with police after a young boy disappears.
Two men are attacked by residents in Masiphumelele for allegedly burgling homes.
Hundreds of protesters join a march, organised by the Muslim Judicial Council, outside parliament in solidarity with Palestinians.

Students at the Tshwane University of Technology riot, stone vehicles and block the entrance to the university before being dispersed by the police with rubber bullets. The TUT had allegedly failed to pay students their bursaries.

Right2Know campaign members and other civil organisation leaders hold a pciket in Cape Town to protest against the Regulation of Gatherings Act which they argue udnermines a citizens right to protest.
Students at the University of South Africa protest for three days over economic exclusion. The protesters allege that increasing fees are being used to bar black students.
Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Edgewood campus protest over admission fees and student funding
Pupils protest, throw stones and hassel pedestrians during a demonstration over the lack of electricity at their school.
Masiphumelele residents riot and clash with police. The rioters were demanding the release of community members accused of engaging in the extra-judicial killing of alleged criminals.
Pensioners protest outside parliament and demand an increase in their monthly stipend.
Students at the University of South Africa protest for three days over economic exclusion. The protesters allege that increasing fees are being used to bar black students.
Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Westville campus torch a building and are pursued by security during ongoing protests against lack of funding and increasing fees.
Residents of Makhubung block the main road with burning debris and demand the installation of electricity in their village.
Employees of a cleaning company vandalise company machines in a demonstration over salaries.
Residents of Kopela burn down three schools and a clinic during a protest to demand water and electricity.

Thousands of people march against government corruption in Pretoria, Cape Town and Durban. The march includes members of the EFF, Right2Know, Treatment Action Campaign and other civil society organisations. The marchers call themselves Unite Against Corruption.
Residents protest over the vandalization of a Hindu temple.

Thousands of people march against government corruption in Pretoria, Cape Town and Durban. The march includes members of the EFF, Right2Know, Treatment Action Campaign and other civil society organisations. The marchers call themselves Unite Against Corruption.

Thousands of people march against government corruption in Pretoria, Cape Town and Durban. The march includes members of the EFF, Right2Know, Treatment Action Campaign and other civil society organisations. The marchers call themselves Unite Against Corruption.
Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Edgewood clash with university security during protests over university fees and funding.
Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus protest over increasing fees.
Dismissed workers at the Avon Power Peaking Plant at Shakaskraal steal scaffolding and use it to barricade the road during a protest against the hiring of new labour.
Students at the University of South Africa protest for three days over economic exclusion. The protesters allege that increasing fees are being used to bar black students.

Around 1 October 2015 (as reported), several foreign-owned shops and houses were looted and destroyed in an outbreak of xenophobic violence in Grahamstown (Eastern-Cape). 458 people were displaced. No reports on injuries and/or fatalities. [size=no report]
A man is severely beaten by commuters after he is accused of stealing phones.
Students continue to protest at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Westville campus over fees and funding. No reports of violence.
150 students from University of KwaZulu-Natal protest outside Pinetowns Magistrate Court where two students are on trial for crimes committed during the recent riots at the university.
Students protest at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Edgewood campus over fees and funding. No reports of violence.

An ANC funder, Wandile Bozwana, is fatally shot in an assassination. The killing is suspected to be related to government tenders and regional ANC structures have been accused of being complicit in the killing. Bozwana had previously clashed with North West Premier Supra Mahumapelo over the allocation of a huge infrastructure government tender amounting to billions of rand.
A man accused of killing two people with a spade is fatally lynched and necklaced by community members.

Two people are shot dead in ongoing political violence in Glebelands hostel. The violence is simultaneously tied to discrepancies and corruption in the allocation of beds and the political conflict between mayor James Nxumalo and councillor Zandile Gumede.
Taxi driver protest over the high number of fines given to them by the authorities and stone police vehicles. The police arrest a number of demonstrators at the scene.

Students attempt to erect barricades on the road at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Westville campus. The students are arrested on the scene by police. The protests are over fees and financial support.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Rioters in Sterkstroom vandalise the mayors house and burn down three other properties. The riot is related to local political matters.

Approximately 200 angry striking Algoa Bus Company employees march to New Brightons town hall and hand over a memorandum to the Department of Transport. The employees are striking over employment conditions and the companies death benefits policy.
Students at the University of Johannesburg protest against the outsourcing of workers at the institution.
Students at the University of Cape Town protest against the outsourcing of workers at the institution.
Students at Wits University protest against the outsourcing of workers at the institution.

column7: CEPPWAWU: Chemical Energy Paper Printing Wood and Allied Workers Union
column17: CEPPWAWU members protest outside the offices of its fund and investment managers, Letsema Consulting. The protesters accuse their investment trustees of misleading them.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Food and Allied Workers Union members continue to strike over wages. The strikers violently engage with police during a protest.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union; United Front; ANC: African National Congress
column17: Striking FAWU members, supported by the ANC and United Front, barricade the entrance to the Ceres Fruit Growers company. The rioters are striking over wages.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU members march against retrenchments and job losses in Durban.
Residents of Atamelang near Delareyville burn down schools during a protest demanding electricity and better service delivery.
The statue of Paul Kruger is defaced by unknown individuals. The vandalism is part of a larger trend of protest groups defacing colonial and apartheid-era symbols.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SACP: South African Communist Party
column17: 2000 Cosatu affiliate members march to parliament to protest against retrenchments and layoffs. SACP deputy chairperson Thulas Nxesi spoke at the protest.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU members march against retrenchments and job losses in Johannesburg.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU members march against retrenchments and job losses in the Eastern Cape.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Members of the National Education and Health Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) occupy the Limpopo department of public works to protest against MEC Jerry Ndou, who did not respond to a memorandum they submitted earlier. The protesters then clash with police.

column7: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: On 9 October 2015, taxi Drivers armed with clubs and sjamboks attack foreigners and alleged drug dealers, who they accuse of robbing their passengers and ruining their trade. A foreign national is stabbed during the violence. [size=no report]
Workers from the Australian-owned Tormin mine march to the Western Cape High Court to protest against unfair labour practices.
Hundreds of Bhisho legislature employees boycott the canteen in the legislature in protest against the alleged ill-treatment of canteen staff by catering company boss Viwe Vazi.
A vigilante mob threatening to burn two individuals recently arrested for robbery throw stones at police after the officers rescue the two suspects. The police respond with rubber bullets.

Parents, supported by members of the EFF, march to demand tha the principal of Parliament Street Primary school be dismissed. The demonstrators accuse the head of refusing to work with the school governing body (SBG) and setting up her own SBG.

Residents of Kya Sand informal settlement in Randburg burn tyres and riot over the lack of service delivery and their possible forced relocation to Brits. The police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets.
An accused rapist is beaten to death by community members.
Four trucks, four buses and two cars are set alight by residents in Burgersfort who demand jobs and development invest from the nearby mines.

column7: Sonke Gender Justice; TAC: Treatment Action Campaign; Section27
column17: Civil society groups TAC, Sonke and Section27 lead a protest outside Johannesburg High Court in solidarity with miners suffering from denegerative diseases contracted during their careers. The miners are suing mining companies for ill-treatment.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: A smaller protest against corruption, also organised by NUMSA, takes place at Nomzamo Stadium in Strand.
Over a thousand residents of Vrygrond protest with taxi owners after the council impounds taxis serving routes without a permit. The demonstrators burn tyres and stone cars during the protest.

Senzakahle workers, responsible for the cleaning of trains at Cape Town Station, hold a sit-in at the station and refuse to be relocated after their contract ends. The workers also fill the trains with refuse and excrement during their protest.
Students at Witts University guard the gates of the institution, not allowing anyone in or out. The demonstration is over a 10.5% increase in fees. No violence reported.
Members of advocacy group Right2Know march through Cape Town to protest against corruption. The protesters cited allegations that telecomms company MTN avoided tax while Cyril Ramaphosa was chairman.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: An estimated NUMSA 50,000 members and supporters downed tools nationally and about 5,000 people marched on the Chamber of Mines and the Johannesburg Stock Exchange to protest against corruption in the Zuma regime.
Witts University students continue to protest over an increase in fees. During the protests university property is vandalised and defaced. There are reports of police attacking rioting students.
Taxi drivers and residents of Vrygrond continue to riot over the impounding of taxis by the council. 25 people are arrested by police during the riot.
Two people are fatally shot during riots by residents and taxi drivers over the impounding of taxis by the council. The shootings are believed to be related to the demonstrations.
Students protest against sexual harassment on campus after a first-year student was allegedly sexually harassed in a bathroom by a male student.

Hundreds of protesters gather outside St George's Cathedral in Cape Town and protest against alleged fraudulent deductions from social grants and pensions. The protest is led by the lobby group Black Sash.
Students at Witts University continue to barricade the entrance to buildings and protest against a proposed fee hike. University security attempt to disperse the riots with pepper spray.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: 200 members of the Congress of South African Students movement (Cosas) storm a school in Germiston throwing stones and vandalising the premises. The action was triggered after three leaders of the organisation were chased off the school premises by the principal when they arrived unannounced to hand over a memorandum.
The Unite Against Corruption coalition protests in Johannesburg against corruption in the Zuma regime.
A senior municipal worker and brother to Richmonds deputy mayor is shot dead in a suspected political assassination.
Taxi drivers burn unmetred cars operating as taxis during a strike. The rioters claimed that the unmetered cars undercut the effectiveness of their strike. The cause of the strike is unknown.

Parents at Samora Machel Primary School protest against the behaviour of one of the teachers. The teacher in question has been allegedly using threats to get shortlisted to the vacant position of headteacher.
Students at the Wits University continue their protest against rising fees.
Striking taxi drivers burn cars suspected of operating as taxis and undermining their strike.
Students at the Wits University continue their protest against rising fees.

On 18 October 2015, locals raided and destroyed foreign-owned businesses and houses in Lebowakgomo (Limpopo). Authorities reported that the residents were targeting men and boys; more than 100 families had to flee the village. More than 8 people were arrested. Injuries and fatalities were not reported. [size=more than 8]

On 18 October 2015, residents of Makurung loot shops owned by foreigners and attack foreign residents over three days of violence. Numerous foreign residents are injured during the riots. [size=no report]
Police fire teargas at students occupying and barricading the Bremner Building at the University of Cape Town. The students are protesting over increasing university fees.
A disarmed criminal is extra-judicially executed by members of the police. The event is caught on camera.
Wits University students in Parktown protest over increasing ffes. During the demonstration a car purposefully runs over a number of students. The students destroy and total the vehicle in response.

Parents at Samora Machel Primary School protest for a second time and demand that a teacher be removed. The teacher has been allegedly using threats to get shortlisted to the vacant position of headteacher.
Students at Wits University occupy the universities Senate House during a protest over increasing fees.

On 19 October 2015, residents of Makurung loot shops owned by foreigners and attack foreign residents over three days of violence. Numerous foreign residents are injured during the riots. [size=no report]
Students armed with sticks and clubs block of Rhodes University during a protest over an annual increase in fees. The police try to disperse the students with stun grenades and teargas.

Students at Stellenbosch University form a human chain to bar police from arresting students. Some students stormed the administration building, breaking glass to get in. Riot police were brought in to control the situation
Students at Fort Hare University hold a mass march after some of them were allegedly informed that they would not be allowed to write their final exams due to outstanding fees.
Protesting pupils from Matthew Goniwe Memorial School in Khayelitsha vandalise the school and call for the removal of its principal.

column7: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
column17: Community organisation Pagad held a march from Gugulethu to Athlone.
Students at the University of the Free State in Bloemfontein protest against increasing university fees.
Students at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology stage a sit-in to protest against a proposed 10% increase in fees. There are reports of vandalism during the demonstration.
Students at Rhodes University erect barricades and clash with police during protests over increasing university fees.
A group of activists occupy the Shoprite in Khayelitsha Mall and demand lower food prices generally, and bread prices in particular.
A family of eight accused of practicing witchcraft are killed by vigilantes.

On 20 October 2015, residents of Makurung loot shops owned by foreigners and attack foreign residents over three days of violence. Numerous foreign residents are injured during the riots. [size=no report]
Police forcibly remove 60 Stellenbosch University students from a building they are occupying as part of a protest against increasing university fees.
Students at Westbury Secondary School protest against insecurity and crime after one of their teachers is killed by local criminals.

Students at UCT in Rondbosch blockade the road in a protest over fees. Some demonstrators are arrested prompting more demonstrators to go to the police station and demand their release. DA leader Mmusi Maimane attempts to address the protesting students, but is chased away.
Students at Rhodes University continue disruptive protests over university fees.
Students at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology stone and loot administrative buildings at the universities Bellville campus. The students are demonstrating against increasing fees.
Students from the University of the Free State peacefully protest and chant against increasing university fees.

column7: Students (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Thousands of students from across South Africa attempt to storm parliament to protest against rising tuition fees. The demonstrators clash with police. The EFF also protest against the fees and engage in rioting.
Protests against rising fees occur at all of the University of KwaZulu-Natals campuses. The protesters hold talks and sing songs about the governments failure to provide free education.
Protests against rising fees occur at all of the University of KwaZulu-Natals campuses. The protesters hold talks and sing songs about the governments failure to provide free education.
Wits students march from Parktown to Braamfontein to protest against rising university fees.
Protests against rising fees occur at all of the University of KwaZulu-Natals campuses. The protesters hold talks and sing songs about the governments failure to provide free education.
University of Pretoria students hold a peaceful protest.
A collective of students march to the offices of Higher Education Minister Blade Nzimande to hand in a memorandum against rising tuition fees.
Protests against rising fees occur at all of the University of KwaZulu-Natals campuses. The protesters hold talks and sing songs about the governments failure to provide free education.
Protesting students at Stellenbosch University confront management over increasing tuition fees. There are no reprots of injury of violence.
Students at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University burn tyres and riot over increasing fees. Police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets.
Students at the University of Limpopo clash with police and stone vehicles during a protest over increasing fees.
North-West University loot the cafeteria during a protest.

On 21 October 2015, the police used stunt grenades to disperse a crowd in Joza township in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) during the looting of foreign owned shops. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]
Students at Walter Sisulu University protest against rising fees before being dispersed peacefully by police.
Students at Walter Sisulu University in Butterworth protest over fee increases and erect obsticles on the road. They are escorted back to their dorms by police.
Students at the University of Fort Hare violently clash with police during protests over increasing fees.

column7: Students (South Africa); DASO: Democratic Alliance Students Organisation; EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; PASMA: Pan Africanist Student Movement of Azania
column17: Police deploy a water cannon, fire rubber bullets and stun grenades at students protesting fee increases, after the protesters burn tyres and blockade the road. Daso (Democratic Alliance Students' Organisation), EFF Students' Command and Pasma (Pan-Africanist Student Movement of Azania) are all present at the demonstration.
Police use water cannons, tear gas and stun grenades to disperse students at University of the Free State in Bloemfontein demonstrating over increasing fees.

column7: Students (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Police use stun grenades to disperse rioting students demonstrating against increasing fees.
students at Durban University of Technology disrupt exams and protest over rising university fees.
Security guards at the University of Johannesburg pepper spray students protesting against increasing fees.

column7: Students (South Africa); DASO: Democratic Alliance Students Organisation
column17: Students at Walter Sisulu University in Alice and East London protest against rising fees and burn tyres before being dispersed by police. DASO took part in the demonstration.
Students protest outside ANC headquarters against rising costs in education.
Students at Sol Plaatje University throw stones at police who respond with rubber bullets. The students were demonstrating against a proposed 8% increase in fees.
Students march peacefully to the provincial legislature to protest against increasing fees.
Students at the University of Limpopo protest peacefully against increasing university fees.
Students protesting against rising university fees demonstrate outside the higher education department.
Peacefully protesting students are dispersed with stun grenades by police. The students were protesting over rising tuition fees.

column16: Xenowatch; GroundUp; Institute for Security Studies
column17: On 22 October 2015, taxi drivers instigated a series of xenophobic attacks in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) after six ritual murders happened in the area. They sprayed slogans demanding that foreign nationals to leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties were targeted, and foreign nationals attacked. The attacks lasted until 26 October 2015. Police arrested 80 people (spread between 5 events). [size=no report]
Students at Walter Sisulu University in Alice and East London protest against rising fees and burn tyres before being dispersed by police.

Grahamstown suffers five days (22nd-26th) of xenophobic attacks by residents after six ritual murders happen in the area. On the 22nd, taxi drivers instigate the riot by spraying slogans demanding that foreign nationals leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties are targeted and foreign nationals attacked. [size=no report]
6000 protesters demonstrate against fees and clash with police.
Residents of Masiphumelele clash with police and throw stones after a community leader is arrested.
The EFF marches in Marikana against the Bapo Ba Mogale Traditional Council. The council allegedly only gives letters enabling employment at the Lonmin mine to non-Setswana speaking people.
Thousands of students converge on the African National Congresss regional offices in Durban to protest against increasing university fees.
Rioting students hold officials from the Department of Higher Education hostage during riots in Pretoria over fees.

column7: Students (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Students protesting against rising university fees riot in Pretoria and vandalise property. The students were waiting for Zuma to address them and their grievances. Police use water cannons and stun grenades to disperse the protest.
ANC supporters attack DA members with knobkerries and sjamboks at the launch of the DA electoral campaign for the 2016 local elections.

column16: Institute for Security Studies; Xenowatch; GroundUp
column17: On 23 October 2015, taxi drivers instigated a series of xenophobic attacks in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) after six ritual murders happened in the area. They sprayed slogans demanding that foreign nationals to leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties were targeted, and foreign nationals attacked. The attacks started on 22 October and lasted until 26 October 2015. Police arrested 80 people (spread between 5 events). [size=no report]
A building at the University of Zululand's KwaDlangezwa campus is set alight by suspected student protesters demonstrating over fee hikes.
A service delivery protest takes place in the villages around Ganyesa.
A small number of students hold a peaceful protest over fees at North West Universitys Potchefstroom campus.
An ANC branch leader and two others are shot dead in Gugulethu by unknown assailants.
