column16: Xenowatch; Institute for Security Studies; GroundUp
column17: On 24 October 2015, taxi drivers instigated a series of xenophobic attacks in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) after six ritual murders happened in the area. They sprayed slogans demanding that foreign nationals to leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties were targeted, and foreign nationals attacked. The attacks started on 22 October and lasted until 26 October 2015. Police arrested 80 people (spread between 5 events). [size=no report]
Residents of the Chatsworth gathered on Sunday to protest a dispute with a trucking company.

column16: Institute for Security Studies; GroundUp; Xenowatch
column17: On 25 October 2015, taxi drivers instigated a series of xenophobic attacks in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) after six ritual murders happened in the area. They sprayed slogans demanding that foreign nationals to leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties were targeted, and foreign nationals attacked. The attacks started on 22 October and lasted until 26 October 2015. Police arrested 80 people (spread between 5 events). [size=no report]
A student protest took an angry turn at the University of Fort Hare yesterday when hundreds of students broke into and looted a bookstore.
The University of the Western Cape (UWC) became the latest campus to close its doors yesterday after hundreds of students marched across the university grounds.
About 450 mineworkers at ASA Metals mine in Dilokong chrome near Burgersfort were yesterday staging an underground sit-in
Students at Durban-Westville and Howard campuses staged a protest.

Walter Sisulu University students march and force Fort Hare University students to join them in their march. The protesters demand a cancellation of student debt. During the protest students kick down doors and use fire extinguishers to spray water under doors.
Student protesters burn tyres at Wits University. It is unknown whether the perpetrators were students who wish to end the protest or students who wish to call off the protests to sit exams.
A group of residents burnt a container and tyres on Monday night, wreaking havoc in the township.
A car is petrol bombed during a protest by UCT students.
President Jacob Zumas bodyguard is shot at his home in Eshowe in a suspected political assassination.
Thirteen students were arrested on Monday after students went on the rampage and clashed with police.
Police fire teargas and rubber bullets in an attempt to disperce rioting residents.
Stellenbosch students protest outside Stellenbosch court during the trial of three students accused of vandalism.
Students at the University of Limpopo loot shops and burn vehicles during a demonstration demanding the cancellation of all outstanding debt.
Students at Durban-Westville and Howard campuses staged a protest.

column16: Institute for Security Studies; GroundUp; Xenowatch
column17: On 26 October 2015, taxi drivers instigated a series of xenophobic attacks in Grahamstown (Eastern Cape) after six ritual murders happened in the area. They sprayed slogans demanding that foreign nationals to leave the area. Numerous foreign-owned properties were targeted, and foreign nationals attacked. The attacks started on 22 October and lasted until 26 October 2015. Police arrested 80 people (spread between 5 events). [size=no report]
Police fired rubber bullets at protesting North-West University students at the Mahikeng Campus yesterday.
Burgersfort miners associated with NUM continue their week long sit-in in the underground mine shaft (26-29 Oct) and demand the removal of two senior managers.
Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals (UKZN) Edgewood campus in Pinetown blockade the entrance to the campus with debris before marching to the provincial education department.
At Cape Town University of Technology students forcible remove staff and students from their offices and classes.
In Rondebosch, UCT workers, supported by students, protest against outsourcing at the university.
University of Western Cape students shut down the campus during a protest over increasing fees. No reports of violence.
Stores are looted and buildings burnt during overnight protests at Wits University.
Residents of Masiphumelele continue to riot for a second day after a community leader implicated in the killing of three drug dealers is arrested.
Hundreds of protesting students marched in Pretoria stoppig at SARS, the SA Reserve Bank and the offices of City Property.

column7: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-); Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: A man accused of stealing livestock is tortured to death by community members. Two police sent to arrest the suspect take part in the killing.
Thousands of EFF supporters have marched through the streets of Johannesburg.
A group of Wits University students went on the rampage yesterday, pelting security guards with stones, burning vehicles and attacking fellow students returning to classes.
Less than a hundred people gathered for a service delivery march to the provincial legislature yesterday.
University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus riot and assault university security guards.
High SchoolPupils in Khayelitsha participated in a protest as they refused to write the provincial systemic tests.
Burgersfort miners associated with NUM continue their week long sit-in in the underground mine shaft (26-29 Oct) and demand the removal of two senior managers.
The Mahikeng campus of the North-West University (NWU) was closed yesterday due to student protests.
Farm dwellers held a placard protest outside a court in Cape Town calling for the evictions to be stopped.

A boy was shot in the head during a service delivery strike in Estcourt, Kwa-Zulu Natal. Residents barricaded the road with burning tyres, tree branches and rocks, preventing anyone from leaving or entering. Police started firing rubber bullets at the crowd and Kwenzakwenkosi was shot in the head.

column7: Students (South Africa); DASO: Democratic Alliance Students Organisation
column17: An Independent Media photographer was assaulted and pelted with stones by protesting students at Wits University on Wednesday morning.
The Polokwane Municipal Buildings are petrol bombed by demonstrators.
Burgersfort miners associated with NUM continue their week long sit-in in the underground mine shaft (26-29 Oct) and demand the removal of two senior managers.
University of Western Cape students again shut down campus, and occupied Robert Sobukwe Road in protest against the universities continued lack of engagement with their demands
Students continued to protest about many issues at the University of TUTS.

column7: CEPPWAWU: Chemical Energy Paper Printing Wood and Allied Workers Union
column17: Employees aligned to CEPPWAWU (Chemical Energy Paper Printing Wood & Allied Workers Union) last week protested at Foskors Richards Bay division entrance for salary format changes
Police used stun grenade and spray guns to disperse a group of about 300 Walter Sisulu University (WSU) students.
A few hundred students and workers from the University of Cape Town (UCT) marched to parliament this afternoon.
A group of Wits University students riot, pelt security guards with stones, burn vehicles and attack fellow students returning to lectures. The police are deployed to disperse the students.
Students returning to classes and journalists recording the protests are assaulted by rioting students.
Angry Masiphumelele residents caused chaos in Simons Town and Glencairn yesterday when they marched through the suburbs.
About 100 people gathered in front of the Grahamstown City Hall to protest against the xenophobic violence that has hit the town and surrounding townships for more than a week.
Residents took to the streets and blockaded a provincial road in protest against poor service delivery.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: Members of the ANC Womens League marched in Pretoria.
Protesters blocked the main road and the entrance to the Drakensberg Gardens Golf and Spa Resort with burning trees and tyres yesterday.
Students at University of the Western Cape riot and demand the elimination of student debt and free registration. During the riot university security staff are severely injured.
More than 100 people from the Wentworth community took to the streets yesterday to warn drug lords that their days were numbered.
Khayelitsha residents allegedly attacked and killed one of three men suspected of having robbed a super-market at the weekend.
Land Invaders, attempting to clear land for the construction of new shacks, clashed with Police who tried to repell their efforts. Police fired rubber bullets in which 4 people were appretly injured.
Students protested at the University of the Western Cape against the use of private security guards to quell unrest on the campus.

On Monday, students and workers occupied vice-chancellor Ihron Rensburgs office and demanded that he immediately end outsourcing. The group was assaulted by private security guards during their sit-in.
Thousands of Masiphumelele residents marched from the informal settlement near Fish Hoek to join others who were demonstrating outside the court building calling for his release.
About a 100 students and workers from the University of Cape Town held a picket outside of Parliament.

Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse a crowd of Egoli informal settlement residents after they vandalised several traffic lights during a protest on Strandfontein Road yesterday. 5 people were arrested during the riot.
During student protests and riots, a guardhouse was set alight.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: ANC Womens Leqgue member gathered to support the trial against Oscar Pristorius in Bloemfontein.
More than 2 000 members of the Rivers of Living Waters Ministry shouted ""Zondo is my saviour"" as they marched through the streets of Johannesburg on Tuesday.
A large group of parents and residents stood outside Noordgesig Primary Schools main gate on Tuesday afternoon demanding to be addressed by Education MEC.
Hundreds of ANC members protested yesterday outside the party's Eastern Cape headquarters, demanding the upcoming Buffalo City regional conference be shelved.
Yesterday, about 200 people marched to the offices of the Cape Town Mayor to demand the restoration process of District 6 be fast tracked.
Desperation for water has turned violent in Jozini. Community members rampaged, barricading roads with burning tyres and boulders and stoning motorists on Wednesday morning.

Riot police fired stun grenades in the CBD yesterday to disperse protesting taxi drivers who used their vehicles to block the intersection at Strand and Adderley streets. Although the protesters barriacaded streets they appeared not to act violently or destructively.

Police officers watched helplessly as private security guards assaulted and pepper-sprayed protesting University of Johannesburg students and workers yesterday. Protesters later burn debris in protest.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of disgruntled eThekwini contract staff took to the streets yesterday objecting to the ""unprocedural"" recent hiring of 100 ""unknown"" workers in the Durban Solid Waste department.
In Greytown, the meeting between a fraking company and farmers and resident was abandoned after protests and concerns over security.
A municipal councillor was severely beaten by residents who were disatisfied by lack of RDP housing.
Around 150 residents of Westlake township protested outside Kirstenhof police station today in criticism against the lack of policing.
A group of about 30 students, accompanied by Equal Education organisers, marched on the Metro East Education District offices in Kuils River.

About 200 protesters, including students and academics from Wits University, say they were kneeling a distance away from the UJ perimeter fencing, their hands up in a show of peaceful non-violence. During the protest, they were arrested en masse. Elsewhere on campus petrol bombs were hurled at a computer lab and at a parked car.

An ANC branch chairman was shot several times in the back while playing a board game (umlabalaba) at a shack just outside the hostel in uMlazi, Durban. Another man was ambushed and killed, while a man from the Eastern Cape was also shot.
Barricades went up again on UCT's lower campus on Friday afternoon as workers marched to the Bremner Building to meet management over working conditions.
Continuing violence in Masiphumelele has claimed the life of an unidentified man who was killed and set on fire in an another apparent vigilante killing in the restive settlement.
Violence erupted and a classic case of comrade versus comrade played itself out in broad daylight during an ANC's rally in Mamelodi East on Sunday.
A police vehicle was set alight and 2 shack razed by a rioting crowd in the Masiphumelele Township.
An unidentified group attack a family withdrawing water in Nongoma. The area has been hit by a severe drought resulting in tensions between different wards in the community.
Hundreds of ANC members from the OR Tambo region marched to the parties offices in Mthatha demanding the national leadership reconvene its regional conference.

Protesters turned cars away ahead of the court appearance of dozens of students and workers who were arrested on Friday for violating a court order not allowing them to protest at the University of Johannesburg campus.

Thousands of residet of Olievenhoutbosch took to the streets in protest over the allocation of RDP husing. Ad the protests became increaingly violent, police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
Eight Langverwacht Landscaping contract workers were allegedly dismissed after participating in an outsourcing rally at Stellenbosch University on Monday.
University exams started in Cape Town on Monday shortly after protesting students set tyres alight at a main entrance to Students also throw bottles at the Vice-Chancellor.

Students marched to Parliament on Monday to see President Jacob Zuma and Higher Education Minister Blade Nzimande. At the same time, NHAWU aligned workers march outside parliament and start a strike. Simulataneously, about 150 students from iQhayiya High School marched to the Western Cape Department of Education to demand an answer from the acting deputy director, Benjamin Schereka, to their list of demands.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Parliamentary staff affiliated to the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) protested over employment conditions for a second day, bringing much of the scheduled work at the legislature to a halt.
About 400 residents marched to the municipality in Addo, demanding closure of the canal within a month.

Residents, who were holding a meeting at a school in the Zineshe area, were allegedly attacked by a group of people, including the Jozini mayor. The attack resulted in at least one person landing up in hospital with a bullet in his jaw.
Members of the Police Union and Residents protested outside the Krugersdorp Magistates Court in soldarity with the accused Police officers of a the murder of suspected criminal.
A man was stoned to death by villagers for allegedly attempting to rape a woman in Machakaneng near Atok, Limpopo
Chaos erupted at UWC today as police used rubber bullets, teargas and stun grenades against rioting students who were protesting against the stand taken by the head of the university council.
A UCT Jammie Shuttle bus was gutted after allegedly being torched early on Wednesday morning at the Mowbray bus depot. Police are investigating a case of malicious damage to property .

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Stun grenades were used to disperse around 200 striking and rioting parliamentary workers, aligned to NEHAWU, outsidethe Parliament buildings in Cape Town.

Police used rubber bullets and stun grenades against waste pickers protesting at a dump site in Pietermaritzburg against plans to stop them collecting on the site. About 20 waste pickers were arrested during the protest

column7: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
column17: PAGAD members marched to Parow last week to demonstrate against crime and drugs.
A third man is shot dead amid ongoing political violence at Glebelands Hostel
A 1000 ANC members and religious leaders marched to the parties provincial headquarters in King Williams Town to highlight their allegations of irregularities within party structures.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Workers aligned to NEHAWU again gathered in their red union T-shirts at the Parliament buildingss in Cape Town

A night vigil at the University of Johannesburgs Kingsway Campus in Auckland Park turned violent on Friday after protesting students tried to get inside the premises of the institution. Police fired rubber bullets forcing the crowd to flee.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: The National Education Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) showed no signs of letting up as it kicked off a fifth day of striking with rousing song inside the mahogany-lined old National Assembly building on Friday.
Community members protested on Friday against KFCs lack of hiring local youth.

Scores of protesting Cape Peninsula University of Technology students gathered at the Bellville campus and extensive damage was done to property, forcing police to respond quickly. Stun grenades and rubber bullets were fired and a number of students were arrested.
A hostel-dweller and member of the ANC was killed by unknown assailants on his way back from a funeral of other who was shot.

column9: Xhosa Ethnic Group (South Africa); Women (South Africa)
column17: Attackers went on a rampage, attacking girls and elderly people at Lower Mngqesha. The attack is believed to be tied to communal conflict within the Kings William Town area.
Workers, joined by some students, have been protesting at NMMU (University) since Sunday.

A service protest in KwaMsane Township, near Mtubatuba, yesterday spread to the N2, and led to police issuing a warning to those driving through the area, with residents threatening to shut down the national route. Protesters burnt a community hall and closed all roads going in and out of the township with burning tyres and rocks for most of yesterday and Sunday.

Protesting CPUT students allegedly set a financial aid building alight for the second time, causing extensive damage. Meanwhile, on the same day, the Reslife building at UWC was set alight while security booths at the Kovacs building were set on fire. Protester were further stopped from entering a court house where arrested protesters are on trial.
About 2 000 ANC supporters marched through the Durban CBD in support of the embattled KwaZulu-Natal Premier Senzo Mchunu
Tempers flared last night in Endlovini in Khayelitsha, with angry residents burning portable toilets and blockading the road in a protest over housing.

A service protest in KwaMsane Township, near Mtubatuba, yesterday spread to the N2, and led to police issuing a warning to those driving through the area, with residents threatening to shut down the national route. Protesters burnt a community hall and closed all roads going in and out of the township with burning tyres and rocks for most of yesterday and Sunday.
Workers, joined by some students, have been protesting at NMMU (University) since Sunday.
UCT confirms that a small group of about seven protesters attempted to disrupt an exam this evening at the Sport Centre on Upper Campus.

Students at TUT university in Pretoria protested at the Soshanguve North and South campuses, demanding all debt be erased. Some went on the rampage torching some of the campus buildings, beating a security guard into a critical state and vandalising campus property
Workers, joined by some students, have been protesting at NMMU (University) since Sunday.
Hundreds of motorists were diverted after a group of more than 100 service delivery protesters blocked the busy R61 for more than seven hours outside Lusikisiki yesterday.
Disgruntled commuters torched a train at a Pretoria station because they apparently grew frustrated as it was running late due to a technical fault.

A stun grenade was fired at a crowd of protesters apparently rattling the gates of the Stellenbosch police station following the arrest of four Stellenbosch University workers on Tuesday.Protesting students set alight bins and other objects.

A youth was attacked by a rival group from another village in violence which has gripped the region. He was pelted with bricks and attacked by youths armed with knives, pangas and knobkerries in front of his teachers and uncles.Some weapons were confiscated by police later when they arrested four youths. he attack is believed to be tied to communal conflict within the Kings William Town area.
Residents of Xhorha in the Eastern Cape marched to Madwaleni hospital yesterday, demanding the departure of the CEO after a baby was found buried in the hospital grounds.

Tensions are high in Isiqalo informal settlement after violent clashes between residents and former community leaders who have refused to step down. Fifteen shacks were burned down and 58 people were left homeless on 17 November during the clashes.

On 18 November 2015, looting of foreign-owned shops started in Grahamstown, hours after a city hall demonstration turned violent when a small crowd of township residents swore and hurled insults at demonstrators. [size=no report]
Hundred march under the COSATU banner to protest the killing of police officers.
A crowd of protesters marched up and down the streets and singing and screaming. The protesters gathered in Braamfontein in support of Pastor Mboro.
Outsourced workers at Stellenbosch University (SU) continued to protest for a second day.
Drivers from the Wescape Taxi Alliance on Wednesday marched to the office of the Western Cape Premier.
Scrap metal dealers attacked a group of metro police in Springfield Park on, hurling petrol bombs and stones at them, which ended with two policemen in hospital and a metro police vehicle burned out.
About 50 students marched from their Quigney residence to the institutions East London campus.
About 100 Sweetwaters residents protested yesterday outside the Buffalo City municipality offices in King William's Town, demanding housing, street lights, a taxi rank and other amenities.
Exams could not go ahead as protesters continued to gather at the Soshanguve campus of TUTs.

""Three armed men jumped the security perimeter fence around an INGO compound and assaulted one security officer and shot another in his arm. He was also assaulted and tied up while the men broke into the office and stole material assets, and money from the safe.""

On 19 Nov 2015, a protest led by displaced foreign shopkeepers over their treatment since xenophobic looting a month ago, almost turned violent yesterday as angry township residents shouted abuse and told them to leave the country.

column7: POPCRU: Police, Prisons and Civil Rights Union
column17: Members of the Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (Popcru) picketed at a number of Cape Town stations to highlight the number of police officers killed over the past year.
An ANC ward councillor was shot dead at his home at Nkaneng in Marikana, Bojanala regional secretary Tokyo Mataboge said on Friday.
A group of about 50 students at TUTS Soshanguve campus disrupted students who were preparing for their examinations scheduled for Friday.
A group of UCT student gathered outside the Wynberg Magistrates Court to support a victim of rape
A crowd rallied outside the Umzinto Magistrate's Courtcarrying placards and during the trail of accused murderers.
Two men were critically wounded after being shot in Durbans troubled Glebelands hostels which has been suffering from ongoing political violence.
About 1 000 people from the ANC marched towards Cape Towns Civic Centre to deliver a memorandum over service delivery.
A group of 100 municipal workers staged a sit-in over an electronic clocking-in system, demanding a return to the old method of clocking-in by signing a register.

column7: POPCRU: Police, Prisons and Civil Rights Union
column17: Popcru members marched to the polices Wachthuis headquarters in central Pretoria to hand over a list of demands.

During a protest, three halls were set alight at the Tshwane University of Technology's Soshanguve campus. Two private vehicles belonging to security guards were also set alight during the student protest.
The wife of a Tavern owner was stoned to death by a mob who accused her of being involved in his death.
Protesters blocked off the N1 highway near the Grasmere Toll Plaza. The group appeared to be protesting over electricity concerns before police dispersed them with ruber bullets.
A group of residents gathered outside the Molemole municipal offices in Limpopo to demand the completion of a R28-million road project which has stood half-done for almost seven years.
Exams were disrupted at the Bellville Campus after the venue was flooded with water. More than 40 protesting Cape Peninsula University of Technology students were arrested by police yesterday.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: SAMWU workers began protest action in Johannesburg
Workers protested in Stellenbosch at the Unversity.
Two buses were stoned and torched by angry residents in Sterkspruit.
